The data provide biophysical evidence that, in addition to reported conformational changes in the four-helix bundle configuration induced by lipid association, lipid binding of apoE is accompanied by reorientation of the tertiary disposition of the NT and CT domains. apolipoprotein E N-iodoacetyl-N′-(5-sulfo-1-napthyl) ethylenediamine C-terminal dimyristoylphosphatidylcholine fluorescence resonance energy transfer guanidine hydrochloride lysophosphatidylcholine N-terminal high performance liquid chromatography Apolipoprotein E (apoE),1 a resident of several classes of plasma lipoprotein, plays a key role in regulating plasma cholesterol and triglyceride homeostasis (1Weisgraber K.H. Adv. Prot. Chem. 1994; 45: 249-302Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 2Mahley R.W. Science. 1988; 240: 622-630Crossref PubMed Scopus (3377) Google Scholar) by virtue of its ability to act as a ligand for the low density lipoprotein (LDL) family of receptors (3Brown M.S. Goldstein J.L. Science. 1986; 232: 34-47Crossref PubMed Scopus (4350) Google Scholar). Transgenic mice overexpressing apoE manifest decreased cholesterol levels on chow diet and a marked resistance to diet-induced hypercholesterolemia (4Shimano H. Yamada N. Katsuki M. Yamamoto K. Gotoda T. Harada K. Shimada M. Yazaki T. J. Clin. Invest. 1992; 90: 2084-2091Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar), while apoE knockout mice exhibit massive accumulation of remnant lipoproteins (5Zhang S.H. Reddick R.L Piedrahita J.A. Maeda N. Science. 1992; 258: 468-471Crossref PubMed Scopus (1836) Google Scholar). These studies emphasize its principal role in lipoprotein metabolism, while other studies suggest an emerging role for apoE in nerve regeneration and Alzheimer's disease (2Mahley R.W. Science. 1988; 240: 622-630Crossref PubMed Scopus (3377) Google Scholar). Studies of apoE structure-function relationship identified two independently folded domains in the protein (6Wetterau J.R. Aggerbeck L.P. Rall Jr., S.C. Weisgraber K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6240-6248Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 7Aggerbeck L.P. Wetterau J.R. Weisgraber K.H. Wu C-S.C. Lindgren F.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6249-6258Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The 34-kDa, 299-residue protein is composed of a 22-kDa N-terminal (NT) domain (residues 1–191) linked to a 10-kDa C-terminal (CT) domain (residues 216–299) via a protease-sensitive loop localized between residues 191 and 216 (see Fig. 1). The NT domain houses the LDL receptor binding region and bears weak lipid binding capability (1Weisgraber K.H. Adv. Prot. Chem. 1994; 45: 249-302Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), while the CT domain accommodates high affinity lipid binding sites (6Wetterau J.R. Aggerbeck L.P. Rall Jr., S.C. Weisgraber K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6240-6248Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 7Aggerbeck L.P. Wetterau J.R. Weisgraber K.H. Wu C-S.C. Lindgren F.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6249-6258Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 8Yokoyama S. Kawai Y. Tajima S. Yamamoto A. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 16375-16382Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). X-ray crystal analysis of the isolated NT domain of apoE (9Wilson C. Wardell M.R. Weisgraber K.H. Mahley R.W. Agard D.A. Science. 1991; 252: 817-822PubMed Google Scholar) reveals four amphipathic α-helices that sequester their hydrophobic faces to form a helix-bundle in the lipid-free state. Our knowledge of the molecular architecture and structural hierarchy of the CT domain of apoE is limited, though selected peptide segments have been crystallized (10Forstner M. Peters-Libeu C. Contreras-Forrest E. Newhouse Y. Knapp M. Rupp B. Weisgraber K.H. Protein Expr. Purif. 1999; 17: 267-272Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Secondary structure algorithms identify a high degree of α-helicity in the CT domain, with three segments bearing potential amphipathic α-helical propensities (11Segrest J.-P. Jones M.K. DeLoof H. Brouillette C.G Venkatachalapathi M. Anantharamaiah G.M. J. Lipid Res. 1992; 33: 141-166Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 12De Pauw M. Vanloo B. Dergunov A.D. Devreese A.-M. Baert J. Brasseur R. Rosseneu M. Biochemistry (Moscow). 1997; 62: 251-263PubMed Google Scholar). Sedimentation equilibrium studies indicate that the CT domain is responsible for self-association of apoE (7Aggerbeck L.P. Wetterau J.R. Weisgraber K.H. Wu C-S.C. Lindgren F.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6249-6258Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 8Yokoyama S. Kawai Y. Tajima S. Yamamoto A. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 16375-16382Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Perugini M.A. Schuck P. Howlett G.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 36758-36765Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar), an observation corroborated by C-terminal truncation analysis, wherein apoE3-(1–272) was shown to be monomeric (14Westerlund J.A. Weisgraber K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15745-15750Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Further, this study also demonstrated that apoE3-(1–244) displayed no binding to very low density lipoprotein (VLDL), thereby designating this portion of the CT domain as an important lipoprotein binding site in apoE. The NT and CT domains have been shown to be capable of mediating their roles in isolation. In the lipid-bound state, the isolated NT domain retains receptor-binding activity (15Innerarity T.L. Friedlander E.J. Rall Jr., S.C. Weisgraber K.H. Mahley R.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 12341-12347Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), while the CT fragment has been shown to possess lipid-binding capability (16Sparrow J.T. Sparrow D.A. Fernando G. Culwell A.R. Kovar M. Gotto Jr., A.M. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 1065-1068Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar, 17De Pauw M. Vanloo B. Weisgraber K.H. Rosseneu M. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 10953-10960Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Interestingly, isoform-specific variations in the NT domain have profound effects on the lipoprotein binding preference of apoE, manifested by the CT domain. The isoforms are distinguished by amino acids at positions 112 and 158: apoE2 and E4 contain Cys and Arg at these positions, respectively, while apoE3, the most prevalent isoform, contains a Cys at 112 and Arg at 158 (1Weisgraber K.H. Adv. Prot. Chem. 1994; 45: 249-302Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). ApoE4 elicits a preference for binding to VLDL (18Dong L.M. Wilson C. Wardell M.R. Simmons T. Mahley R.W. Weisgraber K.H. Agard D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 22358-22365Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19Dong L.M. Weisgraber K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 19053-19057Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar), while apoE2 and E3 interact preferentially with high density lipoproteins (1Weisgraber K.H. Adv. Prot. Chem. 1994; 45: 249-302Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In the intact protein the structural organization of the two domains with respect to each other is not known. The report of a salt bridge (between Arg-61 in the NT domain and Glu-255 in the CT domain) directing the binding preference of apoE4 for VLDL (18Dong L.M. Wilson C. Wardell M.R. Simmons T. Mahley R.W. Weisgraber K.H. Agard D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 22358-22365Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19Dong L.M. Weisgraber K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 19053-19057Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar) has invoked the concept of domain interactions. This concept is further emphasized in the isoform-specific variability demonstrated in the interaction between apoE and amyloid beta peptide, mediated by the CT domain (20Strittmatter W.J. Weisgraber K.H. Huang D.Y. Dong L.-M. Salsesen G.S. Pericak-Vance M. Schmechel D. Saunders A.M. Goldgaber D. Roses A.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 8098-8102Crossref PubMed Scopus (1238) Google Scholar). Morrow et al. (21Morrow J.A. Segall M.L. Lund-Katz S. Phillips M.C. Knapp M. Rupp B. Weisgraber K.H. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 11657-11666Crossref PubMed Scopus (264) Google Scholar) observed that the NT domain determines the differences in stability among the apoE isoforms. Finally, the observation that lipoprotein-bound apoE displays variable receptor binding ability (22Windler E. Chao Y. Havel R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 5475-5480Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) has led to the proposal that the CT domain anchors the protein to the lipid surface, while the NT domain undergoes reversible conformational changes that modulate receptor binding activity (23Narayanswami V. Ryan R.O. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2000; 1483: 15-36Crossref PubMed Scopus (157) Google Scholar). As lipid binding modulates the functional capability of apoE, it is important to understand the structural disposition of apoE domains in solution and alterations that may occur upon lipid binding. Recently, it was demonstrated that lipid binding induces gross structural changes in isolated apoE3 NT fragment involving reorganization of the helices following opening of the helix bundle (24Fisher C.A. Narayanaswami V. Ryan R.O. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 33601-33606Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar, 25Lu B. Morrow J.A. Weisgraber K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 20775-20781Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). In the present study, we have used a combination of site-directed mutagenesis and steady state fluorescence techniques to probe spatial relationships between the NT and CT domains in apoE3 in aqueous and lipid-bound environments. Site-directed mutagenesis was carried out using the QuikChange™ kit (Stratagene, La Jolla). ApoE3, containing a single reactive cysteine residue at position 112 in the NT domain was used throughout the studies. In one of the variants, designated apoE3/[email protected], all but one (Trp-264) of the seven Trp residues in wild-type apoE3 were mutated to Phe, yielding a protein with a single Trp in the CT domain. Another variant, termed apoE3/Trp-null, wherein all the seven Trps were mutated to Phe, was also constructed. DNA sequencing was carried out to confirm the presence of the desired mutations and the lack of undesired mutations. Recombinant human apoE3 variants were expressed in E. coli using the IMPACT™-CN system (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA). The apoE3 coding sequence is harbored in the expression vector pTYB2, immediately upstream of a protein-splicing element with inducible self-cleavage activity. Following expression, intact apoE3 was recovered by affinity chromatography followed by further purification by reversed-phase HPLC as described previously (26Narayanaswami V. Wang J. Kay C.M. Scraba D.G. Ryan R.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 26855-26862Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar), yielding a preparation of ≥98% purity. Circular dichroism spectroscopy revealed that the mutations introduced into apoE3 did not affect the overall secondary structural characteristics of the protein. Sedimentation ultracentrifugation experiments of apoE3/[email protected] and apoE3/Trp null in aqueous buffer demonstrated that the proteins exist as tetramers and higher state oligomers as reported by others (7Aggerbeck L.P. Wetterau J.R. Weisgraber K.H. Wu C-S.C. Lindgren F.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6249-6258Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 8Yokoyama S. Kawai Y. Tajima S. Yamamoto A. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 16375-16382Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Perugini M.A. Schuck P. Howlett G.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 36758-36765Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). Covalent labeling of apoE3 byN-iodoacetyl-N′-(5-sulfo-1-naphthyl) ethylenediamine (AEDANS) (Sigma) was carried out as described previously (24Fisher C.A. Narayanaswami V. Ryan R.O. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 33601-33606Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). The labeling was stoichiometric, as determined from absorption spectroscopy using the following molar extinction coefficients: 6500 m−1 cm−1 at 340 nm for AEDANS, 11,040 m−1 cm−1 for apoE3/[email protected] and 5380 m−1cm −1 for apoE3/Trp-null at 279 nm. Fluorescence analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer LS50B Luminescence Spectrometer using 5-nm slit width for both excitation and emission monochromators. Emission spectra were recorded using an excitation wavelength of 292 nm to selectively excite tryptophan. Unless otherwise stated, all measurements were carried out in 100 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8 at room temperature. A blank spectrum of buffer alone was subtracted from all spectra. The optical density of the samples was maintained below 0.1 to avoid inner filter effects. To examine the effect of aqueous quenchers, apoE3/[email protected] or AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] were treated with increasing concentrations of potassium iodide (KI) or acrylamide. KI solutions contained 1 mm sodium thiosulfate to suppress free iodine formation. Fluorescence intensities were measured at 348 nm for Trp and 471 nm for AEDANS emission. The effective quenching constants were determined based on the Stern-Volmer equation, Fo/F = 1 + KSV [Q], where Fo and F are the fluorescence intensities in the absence and presence of quencher, respectively, and [Q] is the molar concentration of the quencher. The slope of the plot of Fo/F versus [Q] is the effective Stern-Volmer quenching constant, KSV (27Lakowicz J.R. Principles of Fluorescence Spectroscopy. Plenum Press, New York1999: 237-265Crossref Google Scholar). Fluorescence quenching of free tryptophan was measured with both KI and acrylamide. For comparison with tryptophans in a known location, apoE3(1–183)[email protected], wherein all the 4 naturally occurring Trp residues were replaced by Phe and Tyr-118 was mutated to Trp, was used. The protein was purified as described previously (28Fisher C.A. Wang J. Francis G.A. Sykes B.D. Kay C.M. Ryan R.O. Biochem. Cell Biol. 1997; 75: 45-53Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). The efficiency E, of energy transfer in AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] was calculated based on alterations in donor fluorescence emission (29Stryer L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1978; 47: 819-846Crossref PubMed Scopus (1961) Google Scholar), and is given by Equation 1,E=1−QDAQDEquation 1 where, QD and QDAare the quantum yields of the donor in the absence (apoE3/[email protected]) and presence of acceptor (AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected]), respectively. Quantum yields were calculated based on a value of 0.2 for free tryptophan in aqueous neutral solutions (30Teale F.W.J. Weber G. Biochem. J. 1957; 65: 476-482Crossref PubMed Scopus (474) Google Scholar). The distance of separationR, between the energy donor and acceptor is calculated as in Equation 2,R=Ro(1E−1)16Equation 2 where R0, the Förster radius (31Förster T. Sinanoglu O. Modern Quantum Chemistry. Academic Press, New York1966: 93-137Google Scholar), is the distance at which the transfer efficiency is 50%.R0 is derived from Equation 3,RO=9.765×103(k2JQDn−4)16Equation 3 where k2 is the orientation factor of the donor and acceptor (a value of two-thirds for k2was used (32Selvin P.R. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 246: 300-334Crossref PubMed Scopus (506) Google Scholar) based on random rotation of the fluorophores),n is the refractive index of the medium, taken to be 1.4 (33Lakowicz J.R. Principles of Fluorescence Spectroscopy. Plenum Press, New York1983: 303-339Crossref Google Scholar), and J is the spectral overlap integral, calculated as described earlier (24Fisher C.A. Narayanaswami V. Ryan R.O. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 33601-33606Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar). FRET was monitored from fluorescence emission spectra recorded with excitation set at 292 nm. For all AEDANS-containing samples, fluorescence emission contribution arising from direct excitation of AEDANS at 292 nm was subtracted. To study the possibility of intermolecular FRET, different proportions of apoE3/[email protected] and AEDANS-apoE3/Trp-null or AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] and apoE3/Trp-null were incubated at 4 °C overnight, and fluorescence emission spectra of the samples were recorded following excitation at 292 nm. Mild proteolysis of AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] was carried out as described by Wetterau et al. (6Wetterau J.R. Aggerbeck L.P. Rall Jr., S.C. Weisgraber K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6240-6248Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The protein was incubated with sequence grade modified porcine trypsin (Promega, Madison, WI; specific activity >5000 units/mg) at a 1:2000 enzyme/substrate ratio (w/w) in 0.1 mammonium bicarbonate, pH 7.8 at room temperature for 20 min. In studies examining the effect of pH on FRET, fluorescence measurements were carried out on apoE3/[email protected], AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] and free AEDANS in the following buffers: 0.1m Tris-HCl, pH 8; 0.1 m sodium phosphate, pH 7; 0.1 m sodium citrate, pH 6.2, 5.1 or 4 (appropriate corrections were made for fluorescence emission resulting from direct excitation of AEDANS at 292 nm at the corresponding pH). To study the effect of GdnHCl on FRET, apoE3/[email protected], AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] or free AEDANS were incubated with 0, 0.025, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.6, 1.0, 2.7, and 4.5 m GdnHCl in 0.1 m Tris-HCl, pH 8, for 16 h at room temperature before analysis. The lipid bound state of apoE3, apoE3/[email protected], or AEDANS-labeled protein was examined in two different environments: micellar state or phospholipid bilayer disc complexes. For micellar state, FRET was evaluated in the presence of 0.4% lysophosphatidylcholine (lyso-PC) or 1% SDS, and Ro was derived from apoE3/[email protected] present in the respective environment. For DMPC bilayer disc complexes, FRET measurements were carried out with the following different proteins or mixtures: apoE3/[email protected], AEDANS-labeled apoE3/[email protected], apoE3/[email protected] and AEDANS-apoE3/Trp-null (1:1 w/w), apoE3/[email protected] and apoE3/Trp-null (1:8 w/w) and AEDANS-labeled apoE3/[email protected] and apoE3/Trp-null (1:8 w/w). Disc complexes were formed by incubation of protein with unilamellar DMPC vesicles (2.5:1 w/w lipid/protein ratio) at 24 °C for 16 h. DMPC vesicles were obtained by bath sonication. The discoidal complexes were separated from unbound protein and vesicles by density gradient ultracentrifugation as mentioned earlier (26Narayanaswami V. Wang J. Kay C.M. Scraba D.G. Ryan R.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 26855-26862Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Human apoE3 possesses 7 Trp residues, located at positions 20, 26, 34, and 39 in the NT domain, 264 and 276 in the CT domain, and position 210 in the loop linking the NT and CT domains. Six of these were mutated to Phe leaving a single Trp at position 264 (apoE3/[email protected]) as a probe in the CT domain. In silico predictions localize Trp-264 at the polar/non-polar interface of a putative amphipathic helical segment spanning residues 225–266 (11Segrest J.-P. Jones M.K. DeLoof H. Brouillette C.G Venkatachalapathi M. Anantharamaiah G.M. J. Lipid Res. 1992; 33: 141-166Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). An initial fluorescence characterization of Trp-264 was carried out to assess its microenvironment in terms of defining its location in the tetrameric organization of apoE3 in an aqueous milieu. Excitation of apoE3/[email protected] at 292 nm yielded a spectrum with maximum emission (λmax) at 348 nm, suggesting a predominantly exposed location of Trp-264. Both acrylamide and KI efficiently quenched Trp-264 fluorescence emission, yielding Stern-Volmer quenching constants, KSV of 4.89 ± 0.13m−1 and 7.54 ± 0.06m−1, respectively (TableI). In comparison, free Trp was fully accessible to the quenchers and displayed a λmax of 355 nm, consistent with values reported by others (34Eftink M.R. Ghiron C.A. Biochemistry. 1976; 15: 672-680Crossref PubMed Scopus (989) Google Scholar). Further, an apoE variant, apoE3-(1–183)/[email protected], wherein the lone tryptophan is located in a reported helical segment was examined. The λmax was relatively blue-shifted (337 nm), and KSV values for acrylamide and KI quenching for this protein were low, indicating a buried location of Trp-118. Crystal structure analysis (9Wilson C. Wardell M.R. Weisgraber K.H. Mahley R.W. Agard D.A. Science. 1991; 252: 817-822PubMed Google Scholar) indicates that residue 118 is located in the protein interior, thereby validating conclusions derived from fluorescence quenching studies. Taken together, the fluorescence data indicate that Trp-264 favors an interfacial or predominantly exposed location in the CT domain.Table IFluorescence emission maxima and Stern-Volmer quenching constants of apoE variantsλmax1-aExcitation: 292 nm.KSVAcrylamideKInmm−1apoE/[email protected]3484.89 ± 0.131-bValues are average ± S.D. from three independent experiments.7.54 ± 0.06Free tryptophan35518.09 ± 0.618.58 ± 0.45apoE3-(1–183)/[email protected]3372.58 ± 0.110.89 ± 0.0041-a Excitation: 292 nm.1-b Values are average ± S.D. from three independent experiments. Open table in a new tab The single Cys at position 112 on helix 3 in the NT domain of apoE3/[email protected] was covalently labeled with the extrinsic fluorophore, AEDANS. The self-association characteristics of the labeled protein were similar to those of wild-type apoE3. The KSV of quenching AEDANS fluorescence by acrylamide and KI were 1.7m−1 and 0.3 m−1, respectively. The crystal structure indicates that Cys-112 is located in a partially buried location in the helix bundle. It is likely that the AEDANS moiety prefers a partially buried interfacial location as well, wedged between helices. Given these characteristics, Trp-264 and AEDANS-Cys-112, represent a favorable donor-acceptor pair (24Fisher C.A. Narayanaswami V. Ryan R.O. J. Biol. Biol. 2000; 295: 679-692Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar, 36Dong W.J. Xing J. Villain M. Hellinger M. Robinson J.M. Chandra M. Solaro R.J. Umeda P.K. Cheung H.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 31382-31390Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar) to monitor spatial proximity and distance relationships between the NT and CT domains of apoE3 by FRET (Fig. 1). Fig.2 shows fluorescence emission spectra of apoE3/[email protected] and AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] in the lipid-free state following excitation at 292 nm. ApoE3/[email protected] yielded a spectrum attributed to emission of the single Trp at position 264. In the case of AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected], a decrease in emission intensity at 348 nm was observed, concomitant with the appearance of a new fluorescence peak at a longer wavelength, centered at 471 nm. This is ascribed to AEDANS fluorescence arising from non-radiative energy transfer from Trp-264. To account for the contribution of fluorescence emission from direct excitation of AEDANS, a mutant apoE3 lacking Trp altogether (apoE3/Trp-null) was constructed. Fluorescence emission of AEDANS-apoE3/Trp-null (Fig. 2) was minimal, indicating the large fluorescence peak at 471 nm in AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] is predominantly the result of FRET. Although small, the contribution from direct excitation of AEDANS at 292 nm has been subtracted from all subsequent spectra of AEDANS-labeled protein. ApoE3 oligomerizes in buffer, predominantly forming tetramers (13Perugini M.A. Schuck P. Howlett G.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 36758-36765Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). Self-association of apoE (8Yokoyama S. Kawai Y. Tajima S. Yamamoto A. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 16375-16382Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) is proposed to be mediated by a predicted amphipathic helical segment spanning residues 267–289 in the CT domain (14Westerlund J.A. Weisgraber K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15745-15750Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Given this organization, the potential contribution of intermolecular FRET to the spectrum shown in Fig. 2 was evaluated using three different approaches. In the first case, FRET was evaluated in apoE3 mixtures where the donor, Trp-264, is present on one molecule while the acceptor AEDANS resides on an apoE3/Trp-null molecule. No FRET was observed when apoE3/[email protected] was mixed in a 1:1 molar ratio with AEDANS-apoE3/Trp-null, as evidenced by lack of appearance of AEDANS fluorescence emission at 471 nm or changes in Trp fluorescence emission at 348 nm (Fig. 3). No FRET was observed following incubation of the mixtures for 10 min to 72 h at 4 or 37 °C. In a second approach, FRET was monitored in AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] mixed with excess apoE3/Trp-null (∼1:10 molar ratio), such that heteromeric tetramers will be formed, in which, on average, each AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] will be surrounded by apoE3/Trp-null molecules that bear neither the donor nor the acceptor. No change in FRET was noted (data not shown), implying that the contribution of intermolecular FRET in lipid-free tetrameric apoE is negligible. Lastly, FRET was evaluated as a function of dilution of AEDANS-apoE3/[email protected] in buffer (from 300 to about 15 μg/ml). If intermolecular transfer is involved, a decrease in efficiency can be expected upon dilution of the protein, when the equilibrium is shifted toward a lower ord

p53 tumor suppressor is a transcription factor that functions, in part, through many of its downstream target genes. We have identified a p53-inducible gene by performing mRNA differential display on IW32 murine erythroleukemia cells containing a temperature-sensitive p53 mutant allele, tsp53Val-135. Sequence analysis of the full-length cDNA revealed its identity as the mouse homologue of the human thiamine transporter 1 (THTR-1). Induction of the mouse THTR-1 (mTHTR-1) mRNA was detectable as early as 1 h at 32.5 °C; upon shifting back to 38.5 °C, mTHTR-1 transcript was rapidly degraded with a half-life of less than 2 h. Elevation of mTHTR-1 expression was found in DNA damage-induced normal mouse embryonic fibroblast cells, but not in p53−/−mouse embryonic fibroblast cells, suggesting that mTHTR-1 induction was p53-dependent. A region within the first intron of the mTHTR-1 gene bound to p53 and conferred the p53-mediated transactivation. Furthermore, increased thiamine transporter activities were found in cells overexpressing mTHTR-1 and under conditions of DNA damage or p53 activation. Our findings indicate that p53 may be involved in maintaining thiamine homeostasis through transactivation of THTR-1. p53 tumor suppressor is a transcription factor that functions, in part, through many of its downstream target genes. These cells were growth-arrested when cultured at 32.5 °C; some clones predominantly underwent apoptosis, whereas others were viably arrested and differentiated along the erythroid pathway. In order to search for p53-regulated genes, we performed mRNA differential display on one of the tsp53Val-135 transfectants (clone 1–5) cultured at 32.5 and 38.5 °C. Clone 1–5 cells when grown at permissive temperature, arrested in G1 phase of the cell cycle and matured along the erythroid pathway, as indicated by increased hemoglobin mRNA and protein synthesis (29Tang P.P. Wang F.F. Leukemia. 2000; 14: 1292-1300Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). Upon differential display with a total of 16 arbitrary 10-mers and 3 poly(T) primers, 5 cDNA fragments were identified that showed increased levels of expression upon p53 induction. The activation of two of these genes, provisionally named DDA1 and DDA3 (36Lo P.K. Chen J.Y. Lo W.C. Chen B.F. Hsin J.P. Tang P.P. Wang F.F. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7765-7774Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar), as they were identified by differential display and were activated by p53, was further verified by Northern blot analysis. The 346-base pair DDA1 differential display fragment hybridized to a transcript corresponding to 3.8 kb in size that showed a pronounced rise in clone 1–5 cells cultured at 32.5 °C (Fig.1A). The induction was first observed at 1 h following temperature downshifting, earlier than that of p21Waf1/Cip1 (Fig. 1A). No induction of DDA1 could be detected in pSV2neo-alone transfected IW32 cells (Neo) cultured at 32.5 °C, ruling out the possibility that up-regulation of DDA1 transcript was a nonspecific temperature effect. Moreover, the p53-dependent activation of DDA1 was consistently observed in each of the five sublines of p53 transfectants tested (data not shown), indicating that the induction of DDA1 was not merely a positional effect due to site-specific p53 integration. We further examined the mechanisms underlying p53-dependent activation of DDA1 mRNA expression. Clone 1–5 cells were pretreated with or without protein synthesis inhibitor cycloheximide for 1 h before shifting to 32.5 °C, and DDA1 induction was analyzed. As can be seen in Fig. 1B, induction of DDA1 mRNA was not inhibited by cycloheximide pretreatment, indicating that protein synthesis is not required for the activation of DDA1 by p53. Control experiments with the Neo-transfected IW32 cells showed that cycloheximide had no significant effect on DDA1 mRNA levels. To confirm whether p53 activated DDA1 at the transcriptional level, cells were incubated with the RNA synthesis inhibitor actinomycin D for 30 min before temperature downshift, and DDA1 expression was monitored by Northern blotting. As can be seen in Fig. 1C, induction of DDA1 mRNA was abolished when cells were pretreated with actinomycin D. These results, together with the robust expression and fast kinetics of its induction, suggest that DDA1 is a potential p53 target gene. 5′-RACE was adopted to clone the full-length cDNA of DDA1. After several rounds of RACE experiments using the cDNAs prepared from clone 1–5 cells and a mouse liver cDNA library as templates, a compilation of sequence data established a DDA1 sequence of 3554 nucleotides. The sequence contains an open reading frame of 1497 bp, with an ATG initiation codon starting at nucleotide 199 and a termination codon stopping at nucleotide 1695. The most upstream ATG is likely to be the translation initiation codon because it is preceded by two in-frame stop codons located at nucleotides 28 and 73, and the nucleotide sequence surrounding it resembles the Kozak consensus sequence (37Kozak M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1987; 15: 8125-8148Crossref PubMed Scopus (4168) Google Scholar). The open reading frame is followed by a 3′-untranslated region of 1859 bp that contains a polyadenylation signal. It predicts a protein of 498 amino acids with two potentialN-glycosylation sites at asparagines 63 and 415. The deduced amino acid sequence, containing 12 transmembrane domains, has 40% identity to the mRFC-1 (38Dixon K.H. Lanpher B.C. Chiu J. Kelley K. Cowan K.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 17-20Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and 90% identity to the human THTR-1 (31Diaz G.A. Banikazemi M. Oishi K. Desnick R.J. Gelb B.D. Nat. Genet. 1999; 22: 309-312Crossref PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar, 32Dutta B. Huang W. Molero M. Kekuda R. Leibach F.H. Devoe L.D. Ganapathy V. Prasad P.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 31925-31929Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar, 33Fleming J.C. Tartaglini E. Steinkamp M.P. Schorderet D.F. Cohen N. Neufeld E.J. Nat. Genet. 1999; 22: 305-308Crossref PubMed Scopus (204) Google Scholar, 34Labay V. Raz T.

The C57BL/6J-Min/+ (Min/+) mouse bears a mutantApc gene and therefore is an important in vivomodel of intestinal tumorigenesis. Min/+ mice develop adenomas that exhibit loss of the wild-type Apc allele (ApcMin/−). Previously, we found that histologically normal enterocytes bearing a truncated Apc protein (ApcMin/+) migrated more slowly in vivo than enterocytes with either wild-type Apc (Apc+/+) or with heterozygous loss of Apc protein (Apc1638N). To study this phenotype further, we determined the effect of the ApcMinmutation upon cell-cell adhesion by examining the components of the adherens junction (AJ). We observed a reduced association between E-cadherin and β-catenin in ApcMin/+enterocytes. Subcellular fractionation of proteins fromApc+/+, ApcMin/+, andApcMin/− intestinal tissues revealed a cytoplasmic localization of intact E-cadherin only inApcMin/+, suggesting E-cadherin internalization in these enterocytes. β-Catenin tyrosine phosphorylation was also increased in ApcMin/+enterocytes, consistent with its dissociation from E-cadherin. Furthermore, ApcMin/+ enterocytes showed a decreased association between β-catenin and receptor protein-tyrosine phosphatase β/ζ (RPTPβ/ζ), andApcMin/− cells demonstrated an association between β-catenin and receptor protein-tyrosine phosphatase γ. In contrast to the ApcMin/+ enterocytes,ApcMin/− adenomas displayed increased expression and association of E-cadherin, β-catenin, and α-catenin relative to Apc+/+ controls. These data show that Apc plays a role in regulating adherens junction structure and function in the intestine. In addition, discovery of these effects in initiated but histologically normal tissue (ApcMin/+) defines a pre-adenoma stage of tumorigenesis in the intestinal mucosa. Loss of APC protein by germ line mutation causes familial adenomatous polyposis, an autosomal dominant cancer syndrome characterized by thousands of lower intestinal adenomas. APC loss is also an initiating event in most sporadic colorectal cancer (1Su L.K. Kinzler K.W. Vogelstein B. Preisinger A.C. Moser A.R. Luongo C. Gould K.A. Dove W.F. Science. 1992; 256: 668-670Crossref PubMed Scopus (1355) Google Scholar,2Rubinfeld B. Souza B. Albert I. Muller O. Chamberlain S.H. Masiarz F.R. Munemitsu S. Polakis P. Science. 1993; 262: 1731-1734Crossref PubMed Scopus (1183) Google Scholar). The best characterized function of APC is its association with a multiprotein complex that facilitates the degradation of the oncoprotein, β-catenin (3Munemitsu S. Albert I. Souza B. Rubinfeld B. Polakis P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 3046-3050Crossref PubMed Scopus (957) Google Scholar, 4Rubinfeld B. Albert I. Porfiri E. Fiol C. Munemitsu S. Polakis P. Science. 1996; 272: 1023-1026Crossref PubMed Scopus (1310) Google Scholar). Science. 1996; 272: 1023-1026Crossref PubMed Scopus (1310) Google Scholar, 5Behrens J. Jerchow B.A. Wurtele M. Grimm J. Ashbrand C. Wirtz R. Kuhl M. Wedlich D. Birchmeier W. Science. 1998; 280: 596-599Crossref PubMed Scopus (1118) Google Scholar). This kinase phosphorylates β-catenin on serine and threonine residues in a domain of the N terminus. These modifications, in turn, initiate the degradation of β-catenin by the ubiquitin-dependent proteasome (6Orford K. Crockett C. Jensen J.P. Weissman A.M. Byers S.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 24735-24738Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (646) Google Scholar). Tomlinson I.P. Rowan A. Pignatelli M. Bodmer W.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 10330-10334Crossref PubMed Scopus (442) Google Scholar, 8Morin P.J. Sparks A.B. Korinek V. Barker N. Clevers H. Vogelstein B. Kinzler K.W. Science. 1997; 275: 1787-1790Crossref PubMed Scopus (3517) Google Scholar, 9Iwao K. Nakamori S. Kameyama M. Imaoka S. Kinoshita M. Fukui T. Ishiguro S. Nakamura Y. Miyoshi Y. Cancer Res. 1998; 58: 1021-1026PubMed Google Scholar, 10Sparks A.B. Morin P.J. Vogelstein B. Kinzler K.W. Cancer Res. 1998; 58: 1130-1134PubMed Google Scholar). In tumor cells bearing mutant β-catenin or APC proteins, free cytosolic β-catenin escapes degradation and binds to Tcf-4, producing a transcriptional regulator that is capable of inducing the expression of growth-promoting genes such as c-Myc and cyclin D1 (8Morin P.J. Sparks A.B. Korinek V. Barker N. Clevers H. Vogelstein B. Kinzler K.W. Science. 1997; 275: 1787-1790Crossref PubMed Scopus (3517) Google Scholar, 11Korinek V. Barker N. Chem. 1999; 274: 16641-16645Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). The largest cellular pool of β-catenin is membrane-associated and engaged in adhesion-mediated signaling via cell-cell contact at the AJ (14Orsulic S. Huber O. Aberle H. Arnold S. Kemler R. J. Cell Sci. 1999; 112: 1237-1245Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The AJ is a highly dynamic structure composed of the transmembrane protein, E-cadherin, and several members of the catenin family, including α-, β-, and γ-catenin, and p120ctn(reviewed in 15). When bound to E-cadherin, β-catenin links adhesion complexes to the actin cytoskeleton in ways that maintain epithelial cell polarity, preserve barrier function, and facilitate cell migration (15Yap A.S. Brieher W.M. Gumbiner B.M. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1997; 13: 119-146Crossref PubMed Scopus (688) Google Scholar). Studies examining the localization of wild-type and cancer-associated truncated APC proteins suggest the involvement of this tumor suppressor in AJ function (reviewed in Ref. 16Barth A.I.M. Nathke I.S. Nelson W.J. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1997; 9: 683-690Crossref PubMed Scopus (488) Google Scholar). By altering the availability of β-catenin for engagement with AJ constituent proteins, APC may indirectly modulate epithelial cell adhesion (17Shoemaker A.R. Gould K.A. Luongo C. Moser A.R. Dove W.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1332: F25-F48PubMed Google Scholar). APC was found co-localized with the actin cytoskeleton and with AJs in the epithelial cells of Drosophila embryos consistent with a role in regulating epithelial cell-cell contacts (18McCartney B.M. Dierick H.A. Kirkpatrick C. Moline M.M. Baas A. Pfeifer M. Bejsovec A. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 146: 1303-1318Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar,19Yu X. Bienz M. Mech. Dev. 1999; 84: 69-73Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Immunohistochemical studies also showed that APC resides in the lateral cytoplasm of intestinal epithelial cells, in regions containing the catenins (20Miyashiro I. Senda T. Matsumine A. Baeg G.-H. Kuroda T. Shimano T. Miura S. Noda T. Kobayashi S. Monden M. Toyoshima K. Akiyama T. Oncogene. 1995; 11: 89-96PubMed Google Scholar). Tumor-associated APC mutations generally cause chain termination and result in expression of truncated proteins lacking the C terminus (21Polakis P. Curr. Opin. Genet. & Dev. 1995; 5: 66-71Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar). By immunofluorescence microscopy, both full-length and truncated APC proteins were associated with the membrane at the apical borders of murine intestinal cells (22Reinacher-Schick A. Gumbiner B.M. J. Cell Biol. 2001; 152: 491-502Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar), suggesting that both forms of the protein are available to modulate adhesive interactions. Epithelial homeostasis depends on the dynamic regulation of cadherin-catenin adhesion complexes at the AJ. The intestinal epithelium is normally maintained by the robust proliferation of stem cells situated in crypts. The progeny of stem cells differentiate as they migrate to the tips of the villi, where they eventually senesce and are exfoliated into the intestinal lumen. To mediate the processes of embryonic development, wound healing, and crypt-villus migration, the AJ must be efficiently disassembled and reassembled (reviewed in Ref. 23Birchmeier W. Behrens J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1994; 1198: 11-23Crossref PubMed Scopus (935) Google Scholar). The importance of the AJ to epithelial homeostasis is illustrated by the observation that loss of AJ structure correlates with tumor formation, invasion, and metastasis (24Troxell M.L. Loftus D.J. Nelson W.J. Marrs J.A. J. Cell Sci. 2001; 114: 1237-1246PubMed Google Scholar, 25Perry I. Hardy R. Tselepis C. Jankowski J.A. Mol. Pathol. 1999; 52: 166-168Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar, 26Perl A.K. Wilgenbus P. Dahl U. Semb H. Christofori G. Nature. 1998; 392: 190-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (1205) Google Scholar). Targeted gene disruption in mice shows that β-catenin is essential for maintenance of AJ activity, as this protein is required for the structural organization of the embryonic ectoderm (27Haegel H. Larue L. Oshugi M. Federov L. Herrenknecht K. Kemler R. Development. 1995; 121: 3529-3537Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). A high expression of E-cadherin reduces the nuclear localization and transcriptional potential of β-catenin (14Orsulic S. Huber O. Aberle H. Arnold S. Kemler R. J. Cell Sci. 1999; 112: 1237-1245Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 28Sadot E. Simcha I. Shtutman S. Ben'Ze'ev A. Geiger B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 15339-15344Crossref PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar). The interactions of β-catenin and E-cadherin, and consequently downstream signal transduction, are also regulated by tyrosine phosphorylation of AJ constituents including β-catenin (29Behrens J. Vakaet L. Friis R. Winterhanger E. Van Roy F. Mareel M.M. Birchmeier W. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 120: 757-766Crossref PubMed Scopus (842) Google Scholar, 30Shibamoto S. Hayakawa M. Takeushi K. Hori T. Oku N. Miyawawa K. Kitamura N. Takeichi M. Ito F. Cell Adhes. Commun. 1994; 1: 295-305Crossref PubMed Scopus (403) Google Scholar, 31Ruora S. Miravet S. Piedra J. Garcia de Herreros A. Dunach M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 36734-36740Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (512) Google Scholar). β-Catenin can be phosphorylated via c-Src family tyrosine kinases (SFKs) such as Fer (32Rosato R. Velmaat J.M. Groffen J. Heisterkamp N. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 5762-5770Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar) or epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) (33Hoschuetzky H. Aberle H. Kemler R. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 127: 1375-1380Crossref PubMed Scopus (673) Google Scholar). Noda M. Deuel T.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 2603-2608Crossref PubMed Scopus (371) Google Scholar). The consequence of β-catenin tyrosine phosphorylation is its dissociation from the AJ (14Orsulic S. Huber O. Aberle H. Arnold S. Kemler R. J. Cell Sci. 1999; 112: 1237-1245Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 33Hoschuetzky H. Aberle H. Kemler R. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 127: 1375-1380Crossref PubMed Scopus (673) Google Scholar, 35Hazan R.B. Norton L. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 9078-9084Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (221) Google Scholar) which, in turn, can cause loss of AJ structure (36Le T.L. Yap A.S. Stow J.L. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 146: 219-232Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar, 37Akhtar N. Hotchin N.A. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2001; 12: 847-862Crossref PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar). Under certain conditions of AJ loss, E-cadherin may be internalized and returned to the membrane of epithelial cells as adhesion contacts re-form (36Le T.L. Yap A.S. Stow J.L. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 146: 219-232Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar, 37Akhtar N. Hotchin N.A. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2001; 12: 847-862Crossref PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar). The importance of appropriate adhesive interactions to optimal enterocyte migration was demonstrated by the targeted expression of E-cadherin in the murine small intestine (38Hermiston M.L. Wong M.H. Gordon J.I. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 985-996Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar, 39Wong J. Rubinfeld B. Gordon J.I. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 141: 765-777Crossref PubMed Scopus (171) Google Scholar). Previous studies in our laboratory showed that Apc mutation also affects enterocyte migration in the intestinal mucosa of Min/+ mice. The germ line of the Min/+ mouse contains a chain terminating mutation inApc, and Min/+ mice develop multiple intestinal adenomas that exhibit loss of the wild-type Apc allele (ApcMin/−). We found that Min/+ non-tumor enterocytes (ApcMin/+) displayed an ∼25% reduced migration rate when compared with theApc+/+ littermate controls and the functionally hemizygous Apc1638N enterocytes (40Mahmoud N.N. Boolbol S.K. Bilinski R.T. Martucci C.M. Chadburn A. Bertagnolli M.M. Cancer Res. 1997; 57: 5045-5050PubMed Google Scholar). This result suggested Apc genotype-dependent alterations in intestinal cell-cell adhesion. To characterize further the effect of the ApcMin allele upon enterocyte adhesion, we examined the changes in AJ structure that occur during the progression from wild-type (Apc+/+) to slowly migrating ApcMin/+ enterocytes and to adenoma cells (ApcMin/−). We extracted enterocytes from the mouse small intestine using a method that preserves cell-cell and cell-ECM contacts and therefore provides an accurate evaluation of thein vivo status of adhesion complexes (41Weyant M.J. Carothers A.M. Dannenberg A.J. Bertagnolli M.M. Cancer Res. 2001; 61: 118-125PubMed Google Scholar). Here we show that diminished β-catenin-E-cadherin association and internalization of E-cadherin occurs in the non-tumor enterocytes from Min/+ mice when compared with their wild-type littermates and toApcMin/− adenomas. These changes suggest that the Min mutation alters the membrane-associated pool of β-catenin in adult animals in ways that reduce cell-cell adhesion and slow enterocyte migration but that nevertheless maintain the histologically normal appearance of the mucosa. The data further support the view that the Min mutation yields a dominant negative effect on Apc function. Five-week-old female Min/+ mice were obtained from The Jackson Laboratories (Bar Harbor, ME). AIN-76A chow was prepared by Research Diets (New Brunswick, NJ). Antibodies directed against β-catenin (clone 14), EGFR (clone 13), RPTPβ/ζ (clone 12), p120ctn (clone 98), and against an epitope on the intracellular portion of E-cadherin (clone 36) were purchased from BD Transduction Laboratories (San Diego, CA). Anti-RPTP-γ (M-18), anti-PTP LAR (R-20), and anti-c-Src (SRC2) (sc-18) antibodies were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology (Santa Cruz, CA). A second RPTPβ/ζ antibody (MAB5210) was generously provided by Chemicon International, Inc. (Temecula, CA). Anti-α-catenin (clone αCAT-7A4) and anti-E-cadherin (clone ECCD-2) antibodies were obtained from Zymed Laboratories Inc. (South San Francisco, CA). Anti-phosphotyrosine antibody (clone 4G10) was purchased from Upstate Biotechnology, Inc. (Lake Placid, NY). Antibody recognizing the extracellular domain of E-cadherin (DECMA-1) and anti-β-actin antibody (clone AC-40), and the proteasome inhibitor,N-acetyl-Leu-Leu-norleucinal (ALLN), were purchased from Sigma. Anti-v-Src antibody (Ab-1) was purchased from Oncogene Research Products (Cambridge, MA), and anti-Src-p-Tyr416 was obtained from Cell Signaling Technology (Beverly, MA). The LSAB2 detection system was obtained from Dako Corp. (Carpinteria, CA). IPs used the protein G kit of Roche Molecular Biochemicals. Reagents and materials for IB analyses were as described previously (41Weyant M.J. Carothers A.M. Dannenberg A.J. Bertagnolli M.M. Cancer Res. 2001; 61: 118-125PubMed Google Scholar). FemaleApc+/+ and ApcMin/+ mice were fed AIN-76A diet and tap water ad libidum. Similar growth and food intake occurred in the two groups. At 110 days of age all mice were euthanized by CO2 inhalation, and their intestinal tracts were removed, opened, and washed with cold phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). Tumors were excised, pooled, and frozen in liquid N2. Enterocytes from the ileum were isolated in the following manner. Sections of proximal small intestine were opened longitudinally, washed with PBS, and inspected for evidence of tumor involvement by examination under × 3 magnification. Enterocytes were removed from 1- to 2-cm segments of tumor-free ileum by lightly scraping the mucosal surface with the edge of a microscope slide. The material obtained by scraping was then washed in cold PBS, and the resulting pellet was frozen by immersion in liquid nitrogen. Frozen cell pellets were stored at −70 °C until the time of assay. Enterocytes prepared in this manner also contained some lamina propria and fibroblasts, although the absorptive enterocytes and goblet cells of villi substantially outnumbered these cell types (Fig.1). Serial sections underestimate the ratio between enterocytes and stromal cells, which were shown by three-dimensional analyses to exceed other cell types by >100-fold (42Potten C.S. Loeffler M. Development. 1990; 110: 1001-1021Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 43Wright N.A. Irwin M. Cell Tissue Kinet. 1982; 15: 595-609PubMed Google Scholar). These preparations, therefore, provided a favorable signal-to-noise ratio for studying the characteristics of post-mitotic, differentiated enterocytes in their in vivo condition. Cold lysis buffer (38Hermiston M.L. Wong M.H. Gordon J.I. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 985-996Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar) was added to the tumors or enterocytes pooled from two mice of the same genotype. Unless otherwise indicated, the proteasome inhibitor, ALLN (10 mm), was added to the lysis buffer. Cells and tumors in lysis buffer were separately homogenized by 10 strokes in chilled Dounces. All subsequent steps for protein isolation were performed at 4 °C. Lysates were centrifuged for 10 min at 12,000 × g, and protein concentrations of supernatants were determined by Lowry assay. Normalized aliquots of each lysate were placed in Laemmli buffer (67 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 2% SDS, 10% glycerol, 0.01% bromphenol blue, and 0.05% β-mercaptoethanol (v/v)) and stored at −70 °C. In parallel, portions of each lysate were pre-cleared to remove immunoglobulins by mixing with protein G beads at 4 °C for 4 h, followed by centrifugation and removal of the beads. After pre-clearing, the same amount of protein from each lysate was reacted with primary antibody for 1 h. Immune complexes were precipitated for 12 h with protein G beads. The beads were washed, and the bound proteins were released in 50 µl of Laemmli buffer. The entire amount of each IP sample or the total cell lysate samples were resolved by 7.5% SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Procedures for IB analyses were as detailed (42Potten C.S. Loeffler M. Development. 1990; 110: 1001-1021Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Washed membranes were stripped by incubation at 65 °C for 20 min in 68 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 10% SDS, and 0.01% β-mercaptoethanol before re-probing. All experiments were repeated at least twice using independently prepared lysates. Hematoxylin and eosin staining of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue was performed, and tissues were examined by light microscopy to document histology. Serial sections of mid-small intestinal mucosa fromApc+/+ and ApcMin/+animals were deparaffinized and rehydrated. Endogenous peroxidases were quenched in 3% H2O2, and the slides were rinsed in PBS. The sections were then incubated at 25 °C for 1 h with a rat anti-mouse E-cadherin antibody (clone ECCD-2). Detection was accomplished using the LSAB 2 system using a biotinylated anti-rat antibody at 1:300 dilution. Enterocytes and tumor cells isolated as described above were washed twice in Tris-buffered saline, pH 7.4, containing 1 mm CaCl2. Pelleted cells were frozen in liquid N2 and stored at −70 °C. At the time of assay, cell pellets were placed in 1 ml of a hypotonic lysis buffer without EDTA, NaCl, and detergent (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.8, 1 mm CaCl2, 5 mm KCl, plus proteasome, protease, and phosphatase inhibitors as described (40Mahmoud N.N. Boolbol S.K. Bilinski R.T. Martucci C.M. Chadburn A. Bertagnolli M.M. Cancer Res. 1997; 57: 5045-5050PubMed Google Scholar)). Cells were allowed to thaw and swell on ice for 15 min, before being homogenized with 30 strokes. Cell suspensions were centrifuged for 5 min at 1,700 rpm. The pellet containing debris, nuclei, and unlysed cells were discarded; the supernatants were centrifuged at 100,000 × g for 1 h. The subsequent high speed centrifugation supernatants (S100) were retained; the pellets (P100) were suspended in lysis buffer containing 1% Triton X-100 and centrifuged as above. The supernatants (detergent-soluble P100) were retained; the pellets (detergent-insoluble P100), suspended in Laemmli sample buffer, were also retained. Aliquots of each fraction were removed for protein determination by Lowry assay. Normalized amounts of the fractionated proteins were resolved by 10% SDS-PAGE and IB analyses performed. Because the migration ofApcMin/+ enterocytes is decreased relative to that of their wild-type littermates (Apc+/+) (40Mahmoud N.N. Boolbol S.K. Bilinski R.T. Martucci C.M. Chadburn A. Bertagnolli M.M. Cancer Res. 1997; 57: 5045-5050PubMed Google Scholar), we predicted that the AJ structure and/or function ofApcMin/+ intestinal cells is also altered. Furthermore, we expected that changes in the AJ would also be found inApcMin/− tumor cells, since these cells may have lost the ability to migrate altogether (14Orsulic S. Huber O. Aberle H. Arnold S. Kemler R. J. Cell Sci. 1999; 112: 1237-1245Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 15Yap A.S. Brieher W.M. Gumbiner B.M. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Oxazolidinones are potent inhibitors of bacterial protein biosynthesis. Previous studies have demonstrated that this new class of antimicrobial agent blocks translation by inhibiting initiation complex formation, while post-initiation translation by polysomes and poly(U)-dependent translation is not a target for these compounds. We found that oxazolidinones inhibit translation of natural mRNA templates but have no significant effect on poly(A)-dependent translation. Here we show that various oxazolidinones inhibit ribosomal peptidyltransferase activity in the simple reaction of 70 S ribosomes using initiator-tRNA orN-protected CCA-Phe as a P-site substrate and puromycin as an A-site substrate. Steady-state kinetic analysis shows that oxazolidinones display a competitive inhibition pattern with respect to both the P-site and A-site substrates. This is consistent with a rapid equilibrium, ordered mechanism of the peptidyltransferase reaction, wherein binding of the A-site substrate can occur only after complex formation between peptidyltransferase and the P-site substrate. We propose that oxazolidinones inhibit bacterial protein biosynthesis by interfering with the binding of initiator fMet-tRNAiMetto the ribosomal peptidyltransferase P-site, which is vacant only prior to the formation of the first peptide bond. Oxazolidinones, which were first discovered at E. I. DuPont de Nemours and Co. in 1983 (1Slee A.M. Wuonola M.A. McRipley R.J. Zajac I. Zavada M.J. Bartholomew P.T. Gregory W.A. Forbes M. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1987; 31: 1791-1797Crossref PubMed Scopus (204) Google Scholar), are the only new class of synthetic antimicrobial agent introduced into clinical practice within the last 30 years. Although these compounds block protein biosynthesis (2Eustice D.C. Feldman P.A. Slee A.M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1988; 150: 965-971Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar), they inhibit neither translation by polysomes (3Eustice D.C. Feldman P.A. Zajac I. Slee A.M. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1988; 32: 1218-1222Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar) nor the poly(U)-dependent reaction (4Shinabarger D.L. Marotti K.R. Murray R.W. Lin A.H. Melchior E.P. Swaney S.M. Dunyak D.S. Demyan W.F. Buysse J.M. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1997; 41: 2132-2136Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). However, oxazolidinones do bind preferentially to the 50 S subunit of bacterial ribosomes (5Lin A.H. Murray R.W. Vidmar T.J. Marotti K.R. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1997; 41: 2127-2131Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 6Burghardt H. Schimz K.-L. Muller M. FEBS Lett. 1998; 425: 40-44Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar) and inhibit the transcription-translation coupled reaction (4Shinabarger D.L. Marotti K.R. Murray R.W. Lin A.H. Melchior E.P. Swaney S.M. Dunyak D.S. Demyan W.F. Buysse J.M. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1997; 41: 2132-2136Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). These agents do not affect the formation of the 30 S preinitiation complex (6Burghardt H. Schimz K.-L. Muller M. FEBS Lett. 1998; 425: 40-44Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 7Swaney S.M. Aoki H. Ganoza M.C. Shinabarger D.L. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1998; 42: 3251-3255Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), but they do prevent the formation of the N-formylmethionyl-tRNA·ribosome·mRNA ternary complex (7Swaney S.M. Aoki H. Ganoza M.C. Shinabarger D.L. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1998; 42: 3251-3255Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Except for two contradictory reports of their effect upon peptide bond formation (4Shinabarger D.L. Marotti K.R. Murray R.W. Lin A.H. Melchior E.P. Swaney S.M. Dunyak D.S. Demyan W.F. Buysse J.M. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1997; 41: 2132-2136Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 6Burghardt H. Schimz K.-L. Muller M. FEBS Lett. 1998; 425: 40-44Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar) and one of no effect in a termination assay (4Shinabarger D.L. Marotti K.R. Murray R.W. Lin A.H. Melchior E.P. Swaney S.M. Dunyak D.S. Demyan W.F. Buysse J.M. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1997; 41: 2132-2136Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), the inhibitory action of oxazolidinones in functional translation assays has not been fully investigated. The lack of clarity surrounding the mechanism of oxazolidinone action suggested to us that more thorough kinetic studies, at different levels of complexity, might prove illuminating. We used detailed initial velocity kinetics studies to decipher the mechanism of action of these inhibitors. Here we show that oxazolidinones inhibit (a) the translation of natural mRNAs; (b) the puromycin reaction that utilizes 70 S ribosomes, initiator fMet-tRNAiMet, and puromycin; and (c) the fragment reaction, which involves 70 S ribosomes, CCA-Phe-X-biotin and puromycin. Furthermore, we demonstrate that oxazolidinones behave as competitive inhibitors with respect to both the P-site and A-site substrates of ribosomal peptidyltransferase. Tight couple 70 S ribosomes from E. coli MRE 600 were prepared essentially as described by Spedding (11Spedding G. Ribosomes and Protein Synthesis: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, New York1990: 1-9Google Scholar) with minor modifications. Bacterial cells (50 g) were suspended in buffer A (20 mm HEPES-KOH (pH 7.6 at 0 °C), 6 mmMgCl2, 30 mm NH4Cl, 4 mm 2-mercaptoethanol, 0.1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 0.1 mm benzamidine hydrochloride). Cells were broken by grinding with prechilled alumina in buffer A (50 ml) followed by the addition of an equal volume of buffer A supplemented with 2-mercaptoethanol, phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and benzamidine hydrochloride. After incubation with RNase-free DNase (30 min at 0 °C), alumina and cell debris were removed by centrifugation at 15,000 and 30,000 × g, respectively. The supernatant fluid was then layered over an equal volume of 1.1 m sucrose in buffer B (buffer A containing 0.5 m NH4Cl) and centrifuged at 100,000 ×g for 15 h. The upper part of the supernatant fluid was collected and dialyzed against buffer A (4 liters, three times). After washing with Polymix buffer (20 mm HEPES (pH 7.5 at 0 °C), 5 mm MgCl2, 8 mmputrescine, 1 mm spermidine, 5 mmNH4Cl, 95 mm KCl, 1 mmdithioerythritol or 3 mm 2-mercaptoethanol), the ribosomal pellet was resuspended in buffer C (Polymix buffer containing 0.5m NH4Cl) and loaded onto a Sephacryl S-300 column preequilibrated with buffer C. Size fractionation was performed by elution with buffer C (400 ml) at a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min. Fractions containing 70 S ribosomes were pooled, concentrated by centrifugation at 100,000 × g overnight, and redissolved in buffer A. Because analysis of the gel filtration fractions did not show any significant contamination with dissociated 30 S and 50 S subunits, the gel filtration step was omitted in further preparations. The procedure yielded ∼50 nmol tight-couple 70 S ribosomes. Synthesis of f-[35S]Met-tRNAfMet was performed as described (12Dubnoff J.S. Maitra U. Methods Enzymol. 1971; 20C: 248-260Crossref Scopus (69) Google Scholar) using purified tRNAfMet and S-100 extract as a source of formyltransferase, and methionyl-tRNA synthetase. The concentration of tRNAiMet was estimated via specific radioactivity of the final preparation as well as by evaluation of the maximum radioactivity incorporation in the puromycin reaction at saturating concentrations of ribosomes and puromycin. Depending on the quality of acceptor tRNA, a typical preparation had specific radioactivity of 0.02–0.03 μCi/pmol. A solution of 6-((biotinoyl)amino)hexanoic acid succinimidyl ester (250 mg, 0.55 mmol), l-phenylalanine t-butyl ester hydrochloride (142 mg, 0.55 mmol), and triethylamine (84 μl, 0.60 mmol) in dry dimethylformamide (5.5 ml) was stirred overnight at room temperature. The reaction was poured into water and extracted with 5% methanol in dichloromethane. The organic layer was washed twice with water, dried over magnesium sulfate, and concentrated. The residue was recrystallized from a boiling mixture of ethyl acetate and hexane to afford 250 mg of the title compound as a white solid. Peptidyltransferase activity using puromycin as a substrate was assayed essentially as described by Monro (15Monro R.E. Methods Enzymol. 1971; 20C: 472-481Crossref Scopus (64) Google Scholar). The reactions were carried out on ice and contained the following components: 36.7 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.4 at 23 °C), 10 mm MgCl2, 266.7 mm KCl, 0.002–0.07 μm E. coli 70 S ribosomes, 0.012–0.8 μmf-[35S]Met- tRNAiMet, 10–200 μm puromycin, 33.3% MeOH, and 1.6% Me2SO. The specifics of each experiment are given in the figure legends. The reaction mixture was stopped by the addition of KOH to a 1 n final concentration after varying incubation times. Following incubation at 37 °C for 20 min, the product was obtained by extracting into ethyl acetate containing 1 mNaPO4 (pH 7.0 at room temperature). The [35S]formylmethionyl-puromycin formation was quantified using a Packard Topcount-NTXTM (Packard Bioscience Co.) after adding Microscint-40 to the organic phase. The fragment peptidyltransferase reactions were performed at room temperature and contained the following components in a 60-μl reaction volume: 20 μl of 3× reaction buffer (37 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.4 at 23 °C), 10 mm MgCl2, and 267 mm KCl, 33% MeOH), 0.15 μm E. coli MRE600 70 S ribosomes, various concentrations of CCA-Phe-X-biotin, 50 μm [3H]puromycin (0.5 Ci/mmol), 33.3% MeOH, and 1.6% Me2SO. The reaction mixtures were stopped by the addition of 0.5 volume of 7 m guanidine HCl with 20 mm EDTA (pH 8.0 at room temperature) after varying incubation times. The quenched reactions were then transferred to a SAM96Biotin Capture plate prewetted with 2 mNaCl. After incubation for 10 min at room temperature, the plate was filtered and washed with 2 m NaCl to remove unreacted [3H]puromycin. The bound biotin-Phe-[3H]puromycin was measured using a Packard Topcount-NTXTM after adding 15 μl of Microscint-20. Ribosomal peptidyltransferase behaves in vivo as an ordered bireactant system (16Green R. Switzer C. Noller H.F. Science. 1998; 280: 286-289Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar) in which the A-site substrate can bind only to the preformed P-substrate·ribosome complex. It was also shown that under physiological conditions, the formation of the first peptide bond occurs via a rapid equilibrium mechanism (17Pape T. Wintermeyer W. Rodnina M.V. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 7490-7497Crossref PubMed Scopus (311) Google Scholar, 18Tomsic J. Vitali L.A. Daviter T. Savelsbergh A. Spurio R. Striebeck P. Wintermeyer W. Rodnina M.V. Gualerzi C.O. EMBO J. 2000; 19: 2127-2136Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). However, the puromycin reaction is MeOH-dependent, and thus the sequence of substrates binding might differ from the physiological situation. Assuming rapid equilibrium conditions (where for a given substrate, Km ≅ Kd), an ordered bisubstrate reaction can be described as in Reaction 1.E+A⇌EA+B⇌EAB→kpE+PREACTION 2 Correspondingly, the rapid equilibrium random Bi Bi reaction can be depicted as in Reaction 2.REACTION2 Reciprocal plots at various concentrations of a competitive inhibitor of the first substrate, the P-site substrate in our study, should intersect on the 1/v axis above the horizontal axis when either A or B is varied (19Segel, I. H. (1993) Enzyme Kinetics: Behavior and Analysis of Rapid Equilibrium and Steady-State Enzyme Systems, pp. 274–329, 749–751, Wiley-Interscience, New YorkGoogle Scholar). Competitive reciprocal patterns for both substrates would distinguish the P-site inhibitor from the inhibitor competitive with the second, A-site, substrate. For the latter, reciprocal plots would show an uncompetitive pattern with respect to the P-substrate and a competitive pattern with puromycin as the varied substrate (19Segel, I. H. (1993) Enzyme Kinetics: Behavior and Analysis of Rapid Equilibrium and Steady-State Enzyme Systems, pp. 274–329, 749–751, Wiley-Interscience, New YorkGoogle Scholar). Inhibitor studies versus the P-site substrate were performed at fixed concentrations of puromycin (150 μm) and 70 S ribosomes (0.008–0.010 μm). Initiator fMet-tRNAiMet was varied from 0.012 to 0.045 μm, and the oxazolidinone was varied from 0 to 200 μm. Competition with the A-site substrate was performed at fixed concentrations of 70 S ribosomes (0.004 μm) and fMet-tRNAiMet (0.1 μm). Puromycin was varied from 12.5 μm to 100 μm, and the oxazolidinone was varied from 0 to 150 μm. Progress curves were measured for each set of conditions, and the initial rates were determined by linear regression analysis. The v versus [S] data were fitted to possible inhibition models using GraFit software. The mode of inhibition was determined from the model which best fits the data, based on standard deviations for kinetic parameters (Km, Vmax, andKi) and by F test estimates. The apparent inhibition constant ( Kiapp) was defined as a slope replot intercept for the varied substrate. Oxazolidinones are known to inhibit the protein biosynthesis pathway (2Eustice D.C. Feldman P.A. Slee A.M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1988; 150: 965-971Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar) as well as the coupled transcription-translation reaction (4Shinabarger D.L. Marotti K.R. Murray R.W. Lin A.H. Melchior E.P. Swaney S.M. Dunyak D.S. Demyan W.F. Buysse J.M. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1997; 41: 2132-2136Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). To refine our understanding of the mechanism of oxazolidinone action, we examined their inhibitory activity in translation systems of various levels of complexity, ranging from mRNA-dependent translation to simple peptide bond formation. The luc+ mRNA translation assay was used to test whether oxazolidinones inhibit translation uncoupled from transcription. Inhibition curves for DuP 721, XA043, linezolid, and chloramphenicol (a non-oxazolidinone control) are shown in Fig.1. The data show that three oxazolidinones inhibit this reaction to different extents. Whereas one of the early oxazolidinones, DuP 721, shows little effect, the second generation inhibitor, XA043, is even more potent than linezolid. The observed incomplete inhibition may result from the presence of endogenous RNA templates in the reaction mix derived from the E. coli extracts. In addition, because the S-100 protein extract is the source of both translation factors and aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases, the level of control over many components in this reaction (including substrates) is restricted. The poly(A)-dependent translation reaction was used to test elongation step components as possible targets for oxazolidinones. Poly(A), rather than poly(U), was chosen as the template because poly(U) translation is insensitive to well known elongation step inhibitors such as chloramphenicol and erythromycin (20Picking W.D. Odom O.W. Tsalkova T. Serdyuk I. Hardesty B. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 1534-1542Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Hall C.C. Bertasso A. Watkins J.D. Georgopapadakou N.H. J. Antibiot. (Tokyo). 1992; 45: 1697-1699Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). The poly(A) reaction, however, is sensitive to various translation elongation inhibitors including fusidic acid, kirromycin, tobramycin, sparsomycin, tetracycline, erythromycin, and chloramphenicol. None of the three oxazolidinones tested was inhibitory in this reaction (Fig.2). To distinguish between initiation factors and the peptidyltransferase site as possible targets, oxazolidinones were tested in puromycin reaction, an assay specific for peptide bond formation. In this reaction, 70 S ribosomes catalyze peptide bond formation using initiator fMet-tRNAfMet and puromycin as P- and A-site substrates, respectively, in buffer containing 30% MeOH to overcome the requirement for translation factors and mRNA. As seen in Fig. 3, the three oxazolidinones tested inhibit peptide bond formation in this assay. The fragment puromycin reaction is the simplest reaction catalyzed by ribosomal peptidyltransferase. Truncated N-protected aminoacylated oligonucleotides with a length of 3 or longer can serve as an alternative substrate to the complete initiator fMet-tRNAiMet in the puromycin reaction (22Kukhanova M. Streltsov S. Victorova L. Azhaeyev A. Gottikh B. Kraevsky A. FEBS Lett. 1979; 102: 198-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar, 23Bhuta P. Kumar G. Chladek S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1982; 696: 208-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). With this in mind, a partial P-site substrate that mimics the isoacceptor end of tRNA molecule aminoacylated with N-protected phenylalanine (CCA-Phe-X-biotin) was synthesized. This molecule was accepted as a substrate in the peptidyltransferase reaction, and known inhibitors blocked the reaction. As seen in Fig.4, oxazolidinones inhibit the fragment reaction with truncated P-site substrate. To probe further the mechanism of action of oxazolidinones, initial velocity studies as a function of inhibitor and substrate concentrations were conducted using the puromycin reaction. To select a valid substrate concentration range, apparent Kmapp values for both substrates were determined. Values of ∼0.01 μm for initiator fMet-tRNAiMet and ∼20 μm for puromycin were obtained. Fixing the puromycin (A-site substrate analog) concentration at saturating levels (150 μm), the initial velocity of reactions catalyzed by 70 S ribosomes in the presence of varying concentrations of initiator fMet-tRNAiMet (P-site substrate) at different concentrations of inhibitor was measured. The results of inhibition using XA043 are shown in Fig.5A. The pattern of lines in the reciprocal plot suggests that XA043 behaves as a competitive inhibitor with respect to the P-site substrate. The best fit of these data to various models of inhibition using nonlinear regression analysis by the Marquart-Levenburg algorithm confirmed this finding. A similar competitive pattern has been observed for linezolid (see Fig.5B). Replots of the reciprocal plot slopes and nonlinear least square fit yielded a Kmapp value for initiator tRNA of 0.015 ± 0.004 μm with Kiapp values of 36 ± 10 μm for XA043 and 83 ± 20 μm for linezolid. The puromycin reaction was used to examine the effect of inhibitors on the A-site. Oxazolidinones behave as competitive inhibitors of the A-site substrate as well (Fig. 6,A and B). Replots of the reciprocal plot slopes and nonlinear least square fit yielded a Kiapp value for puromycin of 15 ± 3 μm with Kiapp values of 10 ± 2 μm for XA043 and 29 ± 4 μm for linezolid. Thus, in any case oxazolidinones are competitive inhibitors with respect to initiator tRNA at the P-site and may also be competitive inhibitors of the A-site, if peptidyltransferase MeOH reaction has a random mechanism of action. In trypanosomes small nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) genes are clustered, and the clusters encode for either single or multiple RNAs. We previously reported on a genomic locus inLeptomonas collosoma that encodes for multiple C/D snoRNAs whose expression is regulated at the processing level (Xu, Y., Liu, L., Lopez-Estraño, C., and Michaeli, S. (2001) J. Biol. Chem. 276, 14289–14298). In this study we have characterized, in the same genomic locus, the first trypanosome H/ACA RNA, which we termed h1. Having a length of 69 nucleotides, h1 has the potential to guide pseudouridylation on 28 S rRNA. The h1 is processed from a long polycistronic transcript that carries both the C/D and h1 snoRNAs. The h1/rRNA duplex obeys the rules for guiding pseudouridylation. Mapping of the pseudouridine site indicated that the predicted U is indeed modified. However, in contrast to all H/ACA RNAs, h1 consists of a single hairpin structure and is the shortest H/ACA RNA described so far. The most common modifications are conversion of uridine to pseudouridine (Ψ)1 and 2′-O-methylation of the backbone ribose. The function of the modified nucleotides is currently unknown. Most ribosomal pseudouridines and 2′-O-methyl groups are dispensable for cell growth. However, both pseudouridines and 2′-O-methyl nucleotides are clustered around the functionally important regions in the RNAs, suggesting their importance. Additional three C/D snoRNAs (B3, B4, and B5) and two copies of the first trypanosome H/ACA RNA, termed h1 RNA, were revealed. h1 is 69 nt long and can be folded into the canonical H/ACA RNA structure but consists of only a single hairpin structure rather than two hairpins connected by a single-stranded hinge and tail regions. However, h1 carries an AGA box at the 3′-end. Two short motifs of h1 in the internal loop base pair with the 28 S rRNA sequence flanking the target uridine. Mapping of the pseudouridines present in this region indicated that U3643 on 28 S rRNA, the predicted site, is indeed pseudouridylated. The h1 is present on the same polycistronic transcript that encodes for the C/D snoRNAs. Like the C/D snoRNAs, h1 is flanked by a stem structure.
