SPECIFIC AIMSGrowth hormone (GH) has been extended to the improvement of metabolic imbalance in many diseases, including autoimmune disease treated with glucocorticoids (GCs), but it is unclear whether GH can be used safely in autoimmune disorders that are treated with GC. Here we focused on the effect of GH on peripheral T lymphocytes under GC excess.PRINCIPAL FINDINGSExpression of GHR mRNA and tyrosine phosphorylation of JAK2 and STAT5b in human peripheral T lymphocytesWe investigated the expression of GHR mRNA in human peripheral T lymphocytes (HPTL) and peripheral mononuclear cells (PBMC). GHR mRNA was detected in both cell fractions by RT-PCR Southern blotting using a pair of primers set on exons 4 and 6 (Fig. 1A⤻ ). The expression of GHR mRNA was down-regulated by treatment with recombinant human GH (rhGH) (data not shown). To determine whether GH can stimulate tyrosine phosphorylation of cellular proteins in HPTL, the cells were treated with rhGH. Recombinant hGH stimulated the tyrosine phosphoryla...

The anti-sequence, a portable element extending from +1 to +15 of the transcript, is sufficient to prevent promoter escape from a variety of strong ς70 promoters. We show here that this sequence does not function with even the strongest ς32 promoter. Moreover, a particular class of substitutions in ς70 that disrupt interaction between Region 2.2 of ς70 and a coiled-coiled motif in the β′-subunit of RNA polymerase antagonizes the function of the anti-element. This same group of mutants prevents λQ-mediated anti-termination at the λPR′ promoter. At this promoter, interaction of ς70 with the non-template strand of the initial transcribed sequence (ITS) is required to promote the pause prerequisite for anti-termination. These mutants prevent pausing because they are defective in this recognition event. By analogy, we suggest that interaction of ς70 with the non-template strand of the anti-ITS is required for function of this portable element, thus explaining why neither ς32 nor the Region 2.2 ς70 mutants mediate anti-function. Support for the analogy with the λPR′ promoter comes from preliminary experiments suggesting that the anti-ITS, like the λPR′ITS, is bipartite. The anti-sequence, a portable element extending from +1 to +15 of the transcript, is sufficient to prevent promoter escape from a variety of strong ς70 promoters. We show here that this sequence does not function with even the strongest ς32 promoter. Moreover, a particular class of substitutions in ς70 that disrupt interaction between Region 2.2 of ς70 and a coiled-coiled motif in the β′-subunit of RNA polymerase antagonizes the function of the anti-element. This same group of mutants prevents λQ-mediated anti-termination at the λPR′ promoter. At this promoter, interaction of ς70 with the non-template strand of the initial transcribed sequence (ITS) is required to promote the pause prerequisite for anti-termination. These mutants prevent pausing because they are defective in this recognition event. By analogy, we suggest that interaction of ς70 with the non-template strand of the anti-ITS is required for function of this portable element, thus explaining why neither ς32 nor the Region 2.2 ς70 mutants mediate anti-function. Support for the analogy with the λPR′ promoter comes from preliminary experiments suggesting that the anti-ITS, like the λPR′ITS, is bipartite. promoter recognition region initial transcribed sequence base pair(s) nucleotide(s) Transcription initiation is a multistep process that begins when RNA polymerase recognizes the promoter and forms an initial closed complex (reviewed in Ref. 1Gross C.A. Chan C. Dombroski A. Gruber T. Sharp M. Tupy J. Young B. Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol. 1998; 63: 141-155Crossref PubMed Scopus (296) Google Scholar). Conformational changes in RNA polymerase and DNA strand opening then convert this closed complex to an open complex ready to initiate RNA synthesis (reviewed in Ref. 2deHaseth P.L. Zupancic M.L. Record M.T. J. Bacteriol. 1998; 180: 3019-3025Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). During the initial phase of transcription, many short RNAs are formed without RNA polymerase leaving the promoter (3Carpousis A.J. Gralla J.D. Biochemistry. 1980; 19: 3245-3253Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar, 4Munson L.M. Reznikoff W.S. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 2081-2085Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar, 5Hsu L.M. Vo N.V. Chamberlin M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 11588-11592Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). This “abortive initiation” phase ends when RNA polymerase moves away from the promoter. The transition to a stable elongation complex is termed promoter escape (6Krummel B. Chamberlin M.J. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 7829-7842Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar, 7Straney S.B. Crothers D.M. Cell. 1987; 51: 699-707Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). This process is poorly understood, although it can have profound consequences on gene expression (8Qi F. Liu C. Heath L.S. Turnbough Jr., C.L. Methods Enzymol. 1996; 273: 71-85Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Promoter escape requires RNA polymerase both to break its contacts with the promoter and to thread RNA properly through the RNA channel. In prokaryotes, all DNA sequences contacted by RNA polymerase in the initiating complex can affect promoter escape (9Vo N.V. In Vitro Studies of the Transcript Initiation Process by E. coli RNA Polymerase. Ph.D. thesis. University of California, Berkeley1998Google Scholar). This initial contact region can be divided into two parts, the promoter recognition region (PRR),1 which spans from −60 to the start site (+1), and the initial transcribed sequence (ITS), which spans from +1 to +20. The PRR is composed of the three consensus promoter elements: two conserved hexamers positioned at −10 and −35 bp upstream of the start site of transcription, which form the core promoter; and the UP element, positioned at −40 to −60 from the transcription start site. The conserved hexamers are recognized by one of several ς factors in the cell, with each ς factor conferring unique recognition properties on the multisubunit core RNA polymerase (α2ββ′) conserved among all organisms (reviewed in Ref. 1Gross C.A. Chan C. Dombroski A. Gruber T. Sharp M. Tupy J. Young B. Cold Spring Harbor Symp. Quant. Biol. 1998; 63: 141-155Crossref PubMed Scopus (296) Google Scholar). The UP element is found predominantly in strong promoters and is recognized by α (10Estrem S.T. Ross W. Gaal T. Chen Z.W. Niu W. Ebright R.H. Gourse R.L. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 2134-2147Crossref PubMed Scopus (162) Google Scholar). Strong promoter contacts promote RNA polymerase binding, but may impede promoter escape, with a concomitant increase in the number of smaller “abortive” RNA products per long “productive” transcript (9Vo N.V. In Vitro Studies of the Transcript Initiation Process by E. coli RNA Polymerase. Ph.D. thesis. University of California, Berkeley1998Google Scholar, 11Ellinger T. Behnke D. Bujard H. Gralla J.D. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 239: 455-465Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar). There has been little investigation either of the interactions of the ITS with RNA polymerase or of its role in promoter escape. Knowledge that the ITS affects promoter escape arises from the serendipitous finding by Bujard and co-workers (12Kammerer W. Deuschle U. Gentz R. Bujard H. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 2995-3000Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar) nearly 15 years ago. They fused a synthetic ITS to the PRR of the strong bacteriophage T5 N25 promoter and found that gene expression decreased 10-fold both in vivo and in vitro (12Kammerer W. Deuschle U. Gentz R. Bujard H. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 2995-3000Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar). They called this synthetic ITS “anti” and found that it could be fused to several different strong promoters with similar effects, indicating that it is a portable element (12Kammerer W. Deuschle U. Gentz R. Bujard H. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 2995-3000Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar). Later, Chamberlin and co-workers (5Hsu L.M. Vo N.V. Chamberlin M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 11588-11592Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar) showed that the anti-sequence decreased promoter strength by impeding promoter escape. At most promoters, 10 nt is the maximum length of abortive transcripts observed. However, promoters with the anti-ITS accumulate both typical abortive transcripts as well as longer transcripts that reach a maximum size of 16 nt (5Hsu L.M. Vo N.V. Chamberlin M.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 11588-11592Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar). The 13–15-nt transcripts observed at promoters with an anti-ITS have been presumed to be abortive transcripts since they accumulate with time, cannot be chased into longer transcripts, and appear to be released from the transcription complex (13Hsu L.M. Methods Enzymol. 1996; 273: 59-71Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The probability of proceeding to a productive transcript at these positions is quite small, suggesting that inability to escape the promoter is correlated with production of these unusual 13–15-nt transcripts (13Hsu L.M. Methods Enzymol. 1996; 273: 59-71Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Understanding the mechanistic basis of the anti-ITS effect will provide a basis for understanding the general role of the ITS in promoter escape. We considered two classes of explanations for the ability of the anti-ITS to prevent promoter escape. First, some property of the RNA/DNA hybrid formed by the ITS might be responsible. For example, the stability of this RNA/DNA hybrid might somehow sabotage promoter escape. Alternatively, an aberrant interaction between this RNA/DNA hybrid and core RNA polymerase could impede escape. This is feasible since both the β and β′ core RNA polymerase subunits cross-link to the RNA/DNA hybrid (14Korzheva N. Mustaev A. Kozlov M. Malhotra A. Nikiforov V. Goldfarb A. Darst S.A. Science. 2000; 289: 619-625Crossref PubMed Scopus (338) Google Scholar). Second, interactions of RNA polymerase with some other feature of the ITS might impede promoter escape. For example, at the λPR′ promoter, an interaction between ς and the non-template strand of the ITS pauses RNA polymerase, which allows time for the λQ protein to modify the elongation complex, rendering it insensitive to termination signals (15Ring B.Z. Yarnell W.S. Roberts J.W. Cell. 1996; 86: 485-493Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar). The purpose of this study is to distinguish between these two possibilities. Contrary to the predictions of a model in which the effects of the anti-ITS are mediated through the stability of the RNA/DNA hybrid or its interactions with core RNA polymerase, we found that the effect of the anti-ITS is ς-specific. Although the anti-ITS inhibits promoter escape at all strong ς70 promoters tested, it does not do so when placed downstream of the strongest PRR recognized by another ς factor, ς32. Moreover, a specific set of ς70 mutants defective in interacting with core RNA polymerase eliminates the negative effects of the anti-ITS on promoter escape. Interestingly, these same mutants abolish the ITS transcriptional pause mediated by ς70 that is required for λQ function at the PR′ promoter. Finally, bases important for the anti-ITS function are positioned similarly in the anti- and λPR′ promoters. We propose that the effect of the anti-ITS is mediated, at least in part, by an interaction between ς and the non-template strand of the ITS. Holoenzyme was reconstituted by incubating core RNA polymerase and a 5-fold molar excess of ς in transcription buffer (20 mm Tris-Cl (pH 8), 100 mm NaCl, 10 mm MgCl2, 14 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 1 mm EDTA, 4% glycerol, 100 μg/ml bovine serum albumin, and 0.05% Tween) at 37 °C for 20 min in a minimum volume of at least 20 μl. Transcription reactions were initiated by diluting holoenzyme 4-fold with a mixture of DNA and NTPs in transcription buffer (e.g.5 μl of RNA polymerase was added to 15 μl of DNA/NTP mixture). The ratio of RNA polymerase to DNA was 2:1 for multiple-round reactions and 4:1 for reactions in which stalled complexes were made. DNA was present at a final concentration of 100 nm in multiple-round experiments and 50 nm in single-round experiments. Linear DNA fragments generated by polymerase chain reaction that contained a minimum of 100 bp of DNA upstream and 60 bp downstream of the transcription start site were used in all in vitrotranscription reactions. Multiple-round reactions were incubated at 37 °C for 30 min, and reactions to assemble stalled complexes were incubated for 20 min. For each multiple-round transcription experiment, two reactions were performed in parallel, one in which transcripts were end-labeled with 100 μm [γ-32P]ATP (10 Ci/mmol) and a second reaction in which transcripts were internally labeled with 50 μm [α-32P]GTP (20 Ci/mmol). The other two nucleotides were present at 100 μm each; and for some reactions, 50 μm [α-32P]UTP (20 Ci/mmol) was substituted for 50 μm [α-32P]GTP (20 Ci/mmol). Internally labeled reactions were stopped by adding an equal volume of stop solution (7 m urea, TBE (890 mm Tris, 890 mm borate, 20 mm EDTA, pH 8.0), 0.25% xylene cyanol, 0.25% bromphenol blue); end-labeled reactions were stopped by adding a 0.2 volume (5 μl) of EDTA stop solution (50 mm EDTA, 0.35 m sodium acetate, and 0.5 mg/ml glycogen). The end-labeled RNA was precipitated by adding 2.5 volumes of 100% ethanol, and the recovered RNA was washed with 80% ethanol, dried in vacuo, and resuspended in 0.5× stop solution. Stalled complexes were generated to assess the activity of ς preparations. The yield of stalled transcripts confirmed that all of the ς preparations for which values are reported in Fig. 4 were of comparable activity. A dinucleotide present at 250 μm and three other NTPs present at 10 μm each were used to initiate transcription that would stall at the first occurrence of the missing NTP. Transcripts were labeled with [α-32P]ATP (N25 promoter), [α-32P]CTP (groEL promoter), or [α-32P]GTP (either template) at a specific activity of 40 Ci/mmol. ApU and a subset of NTPs were used to form complexes that stall at +18 on the N25 promoter (see Fig. 1, template A), whereas CpA and a subset of NTPs were required to form complexes that initiate at −1 and stall at +18 on the groEL promoter (see Fig. 1, template C). Reactions were stopped by adding an equal volume of stop solution. To determine if transcription at the groELpromoter starts at the A marked as +1 in Fig. 1, as previously reported (21Cowing D.W. Mecsas J. Record M.T. Gross C.A. J. Mol. Biol. 1989; 210: 521-530Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar), RNA transcripts from a multiple-round reaction were labeled with either [γ-32P]ATP or [α-32P]CTP, and the mobility of the abortive products was the same as that of the stalled complexes, demonstrating that +1 is the natural start site (data not shown). Samples were heat-denatured and electrophoresed through a 20% denaturing 7 murea/TBE-acrylamide gel (9:1 acrylamide/bisacrylamide) and visualized by autoradiography, and the products were quantified using ImageQuant software (Molecular Dynamics, Inc.). If the yield of the abortive and runoff products is known, then the probability that a transcript will abort rather than extend to the next position, defined here as abortive probability, can be calculated from the following equation (13Hsu L.M. Methods Enzymol. 1996; 273: 59-71Crossref PubMed Google Scholar):Pi=Xii=full lengthΣXii=iEquation 1 where Pi is the probability at theith position and Xi is the yield of transcript at the ith position. After normalizing for the specific activity of the transcripts, the abortive probability profile was not found to vary at positions beyond +3 irrespective of how the transcripts were labeled (e.g. [γ-32P]ATP, [α-32P]UTP, or [α-32P]GTP), length of incubation time (e.g. 5 or 20 min), or whether transcription was initiated with a dinucleotide and stalled by withholding an NTP (e.g. at +18 for the N25 promoter) (data not shown). The means ± S.D. of the observed abortive probability from at least 10 independent different experiments for wild-type ς70and at least three independent experiments for the ς70mutants are reported in Figs. 2 and 4. To determine the effect of the ITS on promoter escape, we used multiple-round transcription assays to examine the promoter escape properties of a series of synthetic promoters with varying ITS regions in the context of a constant PRR. The multiple-round transcription reactions fulfilled two criteria: 1) products accumulated throughout the time course of the assay, and 2) very few transcribing complexes were “moribund” (committed solely to the production of abortive products) (data not shown and Ref. 22Kubori T. Shimamoto N. J. Mol. Biol. 1996; 256: 449-457Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). The RNA products were either end-labeled, allowing visualization of every abortive product, or internally labeled, allowing visualization of only those abortive products containing the labeled base. Use of different internal labels allowed accurate assignment of the identity of the different abortive products. RNA products were separated by size and quantified, allowing us to calculate the probability that transcription would abort at each position. We refer to this quantity as the abortive probability, which has been defined by Hsu (13Hsu L.M. Methods Enzymol. 1996; 273: 59-71Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) as follows: moles of transcript at any position divided by total moles of transcript of a size equal to or greater than the chosen position. We acknowledge that the short transcripts in question may or may not be true abortive products as defined by two criteria: 1) release from the transcription complex and 2) reestablishment of an open complex that is capable of reinitiating transcription. Each experiment consisted of two independent reactions performed in parallel, one end-labeled and a second internally labeled. After correcting for differences in the specific activity of the transcripts, we found that abortive probability was unaffected by choice of label. In another protocol, we assembled stalled elongation complexes by priming with a dinucleotide and withholding one of the substrates. The abortive probabilities at all positions except +3 were the same as those observed in multiple-round experiments (data not shown). Thus, the abortive probability at each position is a highly reproducible profile of promoter escape and allows comparison of different reactions. This measure is insensitive to factors that can affect the total yield of products such as DNA or RNA polymerase concentration since the products are normalized to the amount of productive transcript. The ITS initially defined by Bujard and co-workers (12Kammerer W. Deuschle U. Gentz R. Bujard H. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 2995-3000Crossref PubMed Scopus (111) Google Scholar) changed bases from +3 to +20. As Vo and Chamberlin found that positions downstream of +15 are unimportant for anti-function (9Vo N.V. In Vitro Studies of the Transcript Initiation Process by E. coli RNA Polymerase. Ph.D. thesis. University of California, Berkeley1998Google Scholar), we fused two ITS sequences, one with N25 sequences from +3 to +14 (Fig. 1, template A) and a second with anti-sequences from +3 to +14 (Fig. 1, template B), to the N25 PRR (see “Experimental Procedures”). In this study, these modified ITS constructs are called “N25 ITS” and “anti-ITS,” respectively. Transcription of the hybrid promoter containing the N25 PRR and the anti-ITS produced many short transcripts that were unusually long and very little runoff RNA (Fig.2A, lanes 3 and4). In contrast, transcription from the promoter with the N25 ITS produced fewer and shorter transcripts as well as abundant runoff RNA (Fig. 2A, lanes 1 and 2). The abortive probability profile for transcription from these two promoters is shown in Fig. 2B. For the promoter with the N25 ITS, the three largest short transcripts are 8, 9, and 10 nucleotides long; the probability of aborting at each of these positions is ∼40%. In contrast, for the promoter with an anti-ITS, the three largest short transcripts are 13, 14, and 15 nucleotides long, and the abortive probability at each of the last two positions is very high. At position 14, the probability that transcription will not advance is almost 90%; and at position 15, the probability is 60%. The high probability that transcription will not advance at +14 causes a strong block to elongation and decreases the amount of productive transcript synthesized. Thus, at the anti-ITS promoter, accumulation of transcripts between 13 and 15 nucleotides in length appears to be a diagnostic characteristic of the ability of the anti-ITS to impede promoter escape. We wished to determine whether the effect of the anti-ITS was specific to ς70 or could affect promoters recognized by other ς factors. We reasoned that if the effect of the anti-ITS was mediated by an interaction with ς, then an alternative ς factor recognizing a different sequence might not be able to mediate anti-ITS function. We chose to use ς32 because its −10 consensus sequence differs significantly from that of ς70 promoters and because its promoters were of comparable strength to ς70 promoters (23Cowing D.W. Gross C.A. J. Mol. Biol. 1989; 210: 513-520Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar, 24Cowing D.W. Bardwell J.C.A. Craig E.A. Woolford C. Hendrix R.W. Gross C.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 2679-2683Crossref PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar). This latter requirement came from the observation that a strong PRR is required for the anti-ITS to impede promoter escape. For example, the anti-ITS is unable to impede promoter escape on ς70 PRRs that either are deleted of the UP element or have a severely disabled −10 consensus sequence (9Vo N.V. In Vitro Studies of the Transcript Initiation Process by E. coli RNA Polymerase. Ph.D. thesis. University of California, Berkeley1998Google Scholar). We considered five different ς32 promoters (groEL, dnaK P1, dnaK P2,htpG, and rpoD phs), all of which are strong ς32 promoters, are comparable in strength to strong ς70 promoters, and contain UP elements in addition to their −10 and −35 consensus sequences (10Estrem S.T. Ross W. Gaal T. Chen Z.W. Niu W. Ebright R.H. Gourse R.L. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 2134-2147Crossref PubMed Scopus (162) Google Scholar). We investigated the strength of these five ς32-dependent promoters by both nitrocellulose filter binding and in vitrotranscription (25Deuschle U. Kammerer W. Gentz R. Bujard H. EMBO J. 1986; 5: 2987-2994Crossref PubMed Scopus (238) Google Scholar). Of these, the groEL promoter was the strongest (data not shown) and was therefore chosen for these experiments. Our initial experiment compared transcription from the authentic ς32groEL promoter (Fig. 1, template F) with that from hybrid promoters with the PRR of groEL and either the N25 ITS (template G) or the anti-ITS (template H). During transcription from the authentic groEL promoter, few abortive transcripts of any size and no abnormally long abortive products were synthesized (Fig. 2A, lanes 5 and6). Neither the N25 ITS (Fig. 2A, lanes 7 and 8) nor the anti-ITS (lanes 9 and10) produced any abnormally long abortive products in the context of the groEL PRR. Furthermore, both hybrid promoters produced equivalent amounts of productive transcript, indicating that the anti-ITS does not impede promoter escape. This experiment suggests that although the anti-ITS impedes promoter escape from the N25 PRR (Fig. 2A, lanes 3 and 4), it does not affect promoter escape directed by the groEL PRR (lanes 9 and 10). One caveat to this experiment is that both the sequence and length of the region located between the −10 consensus sequence and the transcription start site differ in the ς32groEL PRR and ς70 N25 PRR. Since this region of the PRR affects abortive transcription (9Vo N.V. In Vitro Studies of the Transcript Initiation Process by E. coli RNA Polymerase. Ph.D. thesis. University of California, Berkeley1998Google Scholar), sequence differences here could account for the inability of the anti-ITS to affect promoter escape from groEL. To investigate this possibility, we constructed a new hybrid PRR that contained the groEL sequence only through −8 and the N25 sequence from −7 to +1 and fused it to either the N25 ITS (template I) or the anti-ITS (template J). Again, no 13–15-nt transcripts were observed for either template, and promoter escape was unaffected (data not shown). We conclude that the anti-ITS is unable to block promoter escape from the groEL PRR. As groEL is one of the strongest ς32 promoters, this experiment suggests that the anti-ITS is likely to be ineffective at all ς32promoters. The inability of the anti-ITS to affect promoter escape from a strong ς32promoter raised the possibility that the effect of the anti-ITS was specific to ς70. The simplest explanation for such specificity is that a specific interaction between the anti-ITS and ς70 mediates its effects on promoter escape. The ς70-ITS interaction required for λQ function provides precedent for such an idea and also led us to consider the possibility that the same surface of ς70 is required for both functions. A region of ς70 required for λQ function was first identified by Roberts and co-workers (26Ko D.C. Marr M.T. Guo J. Roberts J.W. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 3276-3285Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar) in a screen for ς70 mutants defective in λQ function (Fig.3B, residues inpink). Interestingly, this region is coincident with a cluster of mutations that we had identified in a selection for ς70 mutants defective in binding to core RNA polymerase (Fig. 3B, residues in blue) (18Sharp M.M. Chan C.L. Lu C.Z. Marr M.T. Nechaev S. Merritt E.W. Severinov K. Roberts J.W. Gross C.A. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 3015-3026Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). Locating the positions of the amino acids encoded by these mutations on the crystallized fragment of ς70 indicates that these amino acids lie along a single surface of ς70 (Fig.3B) (27Malhotra A. Severinova E. Darst S.A. Cell. 1996; 87: 127-136Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (265) Google Scholar). All of the ς70 mutants within this cluster that have been tested for λQ function are impaired (18Sharp M.M. Chan C.L. Lu C.Z. Marr M.T. Nechaev S. Merritt E.W. Severinov K. Roberts J.W. Gross C.A. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 3015-3026Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar, 26Ko D.C. Marr M.T. Guo J. Roberts J.W. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 3276-3285Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). The defect in λQ function is a particular property of the binding-defective ς70 mutants from this surface of ς70; ς70 mutants defective in core binding elsewhere in ς70 do not show this phenotype (18Sharp M.M. Chan C.L. Lu C.Z. Marr M.T. Nechaev S. Merritt E.W. Severinov K. Roberts J.W. Gross C.A. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 3015-3026Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). For example, P504A has a decreased affinity for core, but does not affect the ability of λQ to modify the transcription complex. We investigated whether the same region of ς70 required for λQ function is also required for response to the anti-ITS. We examined the promoter escape behavior of four ς70 core binding-defective mutants altered in the cluster of residues previously identified to be important forλQ function. In addition, we examined the promoter escape behavior of a single core binding-defective mutant from each of the other regions of ς70 (Fig.3A). We found that the binding-defective ς70mutants altering the cluster of residues required forλQ function were unable to mediate anti-ITS function, i.e. in these mutants, escape from a promoter with an anti-ITS was not impeded. In contrast, binding-defective mutants from other regions of ς70 had no effect on anti-ITS function. A representative transcription profile of one ς70 mutant of each type is shown in Fig.3C. Accumulation of transcripts 13–15 nt in size is diagnostic of the anti-ITS phenotype. We therefore compared the abortive probability for each mutant ς (Fig. 4A,colored bars) with that for wild-type ς (black bars surrounding the data for mutant ς proteins) at transcript positions 12–15. Mutational alteration of the cluster of residues associated with λQ function (Q406A, D403A, E407K, L384A, and E407A) showed

Recent studies strongly suggest that surfactant protein D (SP-D) plays important roles in pulmonary host defense and the regulation of immune and inflammatory reactions in the lung. Although SP-D can bind to alveolar macrophages and can elicit their chemotaxis, relatively little is known about the direct cellular consequences of SP-D on the function of these cells. Because matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are synthesized in increased amounts in response to various proinflammatory stimuli, we investigated the capacity of SP-D to modulate the production of MMPs by freshly isolated human alveolar macrophages. Unexpectedly we found that recombinant rat SP-D dodecamers selectively induce the biosynthesis of collagenase-1 (MMP-1), stromelysin (MMP-3), and macrophage elastase (MMP-12) without significantly increasing the production of tumor necrosis factor α and interleukin-1β. SP-D did not alter the production of these MMPs by fibroblasts. Phosphatidylinositol, a surfactant-associated ligand that interacts with the carboxyl-terminal neck and carbohydrate recognition domains of SP-D, inhibited the SP-D-dependent increase in MMP biosynthesis. A trimeric, recombinant protein consisting of only the neck and carbohydrate recognition domain did not augment metalloproteinase production, suggesting that the stimulatory effect on MMP production depends on an appropriate spatial presentation of trimeric lectin domains. Although SP-D dodecamers can selectively augment metalloproteinase activity in vitro, this effect may be competitively inhibited by tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases or surfactant-associated ligands in vivo. Although SP-D can bind to alveolar macrophages and can elicit their chemotaxis, relatively little is known about the direct cellular consequences of SP-D on the function of these cells. Phosphatidylinositol, a surfactant-associated ligand that interacts with the carboxyl-terminal neck and carbohydrate recognition domains of SP-D, inhibited the SP-D-dependent increase in MMP biosynthesis. A trimeric, recombinant protein consisting of only the neck and carbohydrate recognition domain did not augment metalloproteinase production, suggesting that the stimulatory effect on MMP production depends on an appropriate spatial presentation of trimeric lectin domains. Although SP-D dodecamers can selectively augment metalloproteinase activity in vitro, this effect may be competitively inhibited by tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases or surfactant-associated ligands in vivo. surfactant protein D matrix metalloproteinase interleukin tumor necrosis factor phosphatidylinositol carbohydrate recognition domain lipopolysaccharide Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium Ham's F12 fetal bovine serum phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate Surfactant protein D (SP-D)1 is a member of the collectin subfamily of C-type lectins that also includes surfactant protein A and the serum protein mannose-binding protein (1Crouch E.C. Respir. Res. 2000; 1: 93-108Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar, 2Wright J.R. Physiol. Rev. 1997; 77: 931-962Crossref PubMed Scopus (503) Google Scholar, 3Lawson P.R. Reid K.B. Immunol. Rev. 2000; 173: 66-78Crossref PubMed Scopus (126) Google Scholar). In addition to membership in this family of immune mediators, there is growing evidence suggesting that SP-D can act as a mediator of host defense within the alveolar spaces and distal airways of the lung. SP-D is secreted as a homotrimer, each trimer consisting of four structural domains: the amino-terminal, cysteine-rich, cross-linking region; the triple-helical collagenous domain; the coiled-coil “neck” (or linking) region; and the globular, carboxyl-terminal carbohydrate recognition domain (CRD) (1Crouch E.C. Respir. Res. 2000; 1: 93-108Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar). While trimerization is sufficient for some of the functions of the protein, SP-D in the alveolar space exists predominantly as a dodecamer, consisting of four identical homotrimeric subunits. This higher order multimerization is thought to mediate bridging interactions, enabling simultaneous interaction with multiple binding partners. Trimerization is required for high affinity SP-D binding to various carbohydrate ligands, and the association with glycoconjugates on bacterial, fungal, and viral surfaces has been attributed to the trimeric CRD region of SP-D (1Crouch E.C. Respir. Res. 2000; 1: 93-108Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar, 4Holmskov U.L. APMIS Suppl. 2000; 100: 1-59PubMed Google Scholar). These carbohydrate-mediated interactions have been suggested to assist in the clearance of pathogens and of certain organic particulate antigens. In addition to carbohydrates, the SP-D carboxyl-terminal domain is also capable of binding to the surfactant lipid phosphatidylinositol in part via the inositol moiety of the lipid (5Ogasawara Y. Kuroki Y. Akino T. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 21244-21249Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 6Persson A.V. Gibbons B.J. Shoemaker J.D. Moxley M.A. Longmore W.J. Cell Mol. Biol. 1994; 10: 430-436Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar, 10Miyamura K. Leigh L.E. Lu J. Hopkin J. Lopez Bernal A. Reid K.B. Biochem. Physiol. 1999; 276: L164-L174PubMed Google Scholar, 12Van Iwaarden J.F. Shimizu H. Van Golde P.H. Voelker D.R. Van Golde L.M. Biochem. Cell Mol. Biol. 1999; 21: 576-585Crossref PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar). In addition, SP-D-null mice show decreased alveolar macrophage phagocytosis of certain bacteria in vivo (15LeVine A.M. Whitsett J.A. Gwozdz J.A. Richardson T.R. Fisher J.H. Burhans M.S. Korfhagen T.R. J. Immunol. 2000; 165: 3934-3940Crossref PubMed Scopus (316) Google Scholar). These cells also have the capacity to secrete several members of the matrix metalloproteinase family including collagenase-1 (MMP-1, Ref. 16Cury J.D. Campbell E.J. Lazarus C.J. Albin R.J. Welgus H.G. J. Immunol. 1988; 141: 4306-4312PubMed Google Scholar), stromelysin (MMP-3, Ref. 17Campbell E.J. Cury J.D. Shapiro S.D. Goldberg G.I. Welgus H.G. J. Immunol. 1991; 146: 1286-1293PubMed Google Scholar), gelatinase B (MMP-9, Ref. 18Welgus H.G. Campbell E.J. Cury J.C. Eisen A.Z. Senior R.M. Wilhelm S.M. Goldberg G.I. J. Clin. Invest. 1990; 86: 1496-1502Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar), and macrophage elastase (MMP-12, Ref. 19Shapiro S.D. Am. J. Respir. Crit. Care Med. 1994; 160: S160-S164Crossref Google Scholar). While the activity of these proteinases likely contributes to both the host defense function of macrophages and to normal tissue remodeling and repair, ectopic or excessive MMP proteolysis has been associated with several pathological conditions including arthritis, cancer growth and metastasis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (20McCachren S.S. Arthritis Rheum. 1991; 34: 1085-1093Crossref PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar, 21Ohashi K. Nemoto T. Nakamura K. Nemori R. Cancer. 2000; 88: 2201-2209Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar, 22Hautamaki R.D. Kobayashi D.K. Senior R.M. Shapiro S.D. Science. 1997; 277: 2002-2004Crossref PubMed Scopus (1241) Google Scholar). To date, few modulators that induce macrophage MMP biosynthesis have been identified, particularly those of host derivation. Both lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and zymosan are known to induce MMP production by alveolar macrophages (23Shapiro S.D. Campbell E.J. Kobayashi D.K. Welgus H.G. J. Immunol. 1991; 146: 2724-2729PubMed Google Scholar, 24Pierce R.A. Sandefur S. Doyle G.A. Welgus H.G. J. Clin. Invest. 1996; 97: 1890-1899Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). Immunol. 1996; 157: 5104-5111PubMed Google Scholar) have also been shown to enhance production of macrophage elastase by mouse peritoneal macrophages. Kalina M. Keisari Y. Podschun R. Sahly H. Chang D. McGregor D. Crouch E. Infect. Immun. 2001; 69: 24-33Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 14Restrepo C.I. Dong Q. Savov J. Mariencheck W.I. Immunol. 2000; 165: 3934-3940Crossref PubMed Scopus (316) Google Scholar), we examined the effect of this surfactant protein on various parameters of alveolar macrophage activation, including metalloproteinase biosynthesis. By contrast with the more generalized activation response elicited by bacterial LPS, SP-D dodecamers caused a selective increase in the production of specific MMPs without concomitant stimulation of proinflammatory cytokine secretion. These effects were dependent on the state of multimerization of the SP-D CRDs and were inhibited with phosphatidylinositol. All chemicals were purchased from Sigma Chemical Co. unless otherwise indicated. All radioisotopes were purchased from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech. Recombinant rat SP-D was isolated as described previously (28Crouch E. Chang D. Rust K. Persson A. Heuser J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 15808-15813Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Briefly, CHO-K1 cells were transfected with a full-length rat SP-D cDNA in the pEE14 mammalian expression vector. Cells were selected for incorporation of the plasmid, cloned by serial dilution, and screened for production of recombinant protein. Conditioned medium from a clonal population was harvested and dialyzed against Tris-buffered saline containing 10 mm EDTA. The dialysate was recalcified and applied to a maltosyl-agarose column equilibrated with Tris-buffered saline containing 2 mm calcium chloride. The column was washed with the same buffer prior to elution of the bound protein with Tris-buffered saline containing 10 mm EDTA. SP-D dodecamers were then resolved from larger multimers and minor lower molecular weight contaminants by gel filtration chromatography under nondenaturing conditions as described previously (28Crouch E. Chang D. Rust K. Persson A. Heuser J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 15808-15813Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The eluted proteins were visualized by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and silver staining, and proteins in the desired fractions were concentrated by rechromatography on maltosyl-agarose. For most studies, the bound protein was eluted with Hepes-buffered saline containing 10 mm EDTA and was stored at −80 °C. Recombinant rat SP-D CRD containing an amino-terminal His6tag was expressed in Escherichia coli (29Vuk-Pavlovic A. Crouch E.C. Limper A.H. Am. J. Respir. Cell Mol. Biol. 1996; 15: A108Google Scholar) and was purified by nickel affinity chromatography. Characterization of the recombinant protein indicated that it self-associated to form trimers as it was eluted from a gel filtration column at the size expected for a trimeric protein. Carbohydrate binding activity of the recombinant CRD was confirmed by its ability to bind maltosyl-agarose. Previous studies have shown that these trimeric mutants retain their ability to elicit chemotaxis and to bind various microbial ligands in vitro (30Cai G.Z. Griffin G.L. Senior R.M. Longmore W.J. Moxley M.A. Am. J. Physiol. 1999; 276: L131-L136PubMed Google Scholar, 31Hartshorn K.L. White M.R. Voelker D.R. Coburn J. Zaner K. Crouch E.C. Biochem. J. 2000; 351: 449-458Crossref PubMed Scopus (123) Google Scholar). The level of endotoxin contamination for both recombinant proteins was quantified using a sensitive, end point chromogenic microplate assay (Chromogenix, Gothenberg, Sweden) with E. coliO111:B4 endotoxin as a standard. The endotoxin content of the purified recombinant proteins used for these experiments was <2 ng/ml or <∼10 pg/μg SP-D for our stock solutions. For individual assays, the stock was further diluted at least 25-fold in endotoxin-free medium, giving final endotoxin concentrations of <80 pg/ml, several orders of magnitude less than the amount associated with detectable macrophage activation in our system. Human alveolar macrophages were obtained by bronchoalveolar lavage of healthy adult volunteer cigarette smokers (minimum, 1 pack/day). For each harvest, 600 ml of sterile saline was introduced and recovered from the right middle lobe and lingular subsegment as described previously (32Senior R.M. Campbell E.J. Villiger B. Adams D.O. Edelson P.J. Koren H.S. Methods for Studying Mononuclear Phagocytes. Academic Press, New York1981: 69-83Crossref Google Scholar). Cells were pelleted by centrifugation and washed three times with serum-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium/Ham's F12 (DMEM/F12, 1:1, v/v, BioWhittaker, Walkersville, MD) before plating in Linbro six-well plates (Flow Laboratories, Inc., McLean, VA) at a density of 2 × 106 cells/ml/well. Cells were allowed to adhere for 1–3 h in a humidified incubator (37 °C, 5% CO2) after which the medium was changed to DMEM/F12 containing 5% fetal bovine serum (FBS). This treatment resulted in a population of cells that were >98% macrophages. Cells were then left untreated or were treated with experimental reagents as indicated and were maintained at 37 °C, 5% CO2. In the case of SP-D preincubation with lipids, recombinant protein was mixed with chloroform-solubilized lipid (Avanti Polar Lipids, Inc., Alabaster, AL) in a microcentrifuge tube and allowed to incubate at room temperature for 15 min prior to addition to cells. Human peripheral blood monocytes were obtained from healthy volunteers. Cells were isolated by Ficoll-Hypaque density gradient centrifugation followed by countercurrent centrifugal elutriation of the mononuclear layer in a Beckman J2–21 centrifuge as described previously (33Boyum A. Scand. J. Clin. Lab. Invest. Suppl. 1968; 97: 77-89PubMed Google Scholar). Isolated monocytes were plated in six-well plates at a density of 2 × 106 cells/ml/well. Cells were allowed to adhere for 1–3 h after which medium was changed to DMEM/F12 containing 5% FBS. Cells were then left untreated or were treated with LPS (2.5 μg/ml) or SP-D (5 μg/ml) and were maintained at 37 °C, 5% CO2. In vitro differentiation of macrophages from peripheral blood monocytes was accomplished by culturing isolated cells for 7 days in DMEM supplemented with glutamine, antibiotics, and 10% autologous human serum with only one medium change at day 1 postplating. Human fibroblasts (American Type Culture Collection no. CRL 1905) were plated in 75-cm2 tissue culture flasks and were maintained in DMEM containing 10% FBS in a humidified incubator at 37 °C, 5% CO2. When cells reached confluence (∼3 days postplating), the media were changed to DMEM containing 5% FBS, and cells were then left untreated or were treated with LPS (2.5 μg/ml), SP-D (10 μg/ml), or PMA (20 ng/ml). Human alveolar macrophages were obtained and plated in six-well plates as described above. 1–3 h postplating, media were changed, and cells were left untreated or were treated with SP-D (10 μg/ml). Media were harvested at the indicated times, nonadherent cells were removed by centrifugation, and media samples were stored at −80 °C until assayed. Eisen A.Z. Collagen Relat. Res. 1983; 3: 205-215Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). Media were harvested at 48 h post-treatment and stored at −80 °C until assayed. Human TNFα and IL-1β immunoassay kits were purchased from R&D Systems (Minneapolis, MN) and were used according to the manufacturer's specifications. Human alveolar macrophages were obtained, plated, and maintained overnight as described above. At 24 h postplating, media were aspirated, and cells were starved in serum-free, methionine-free DMEM/F12. After 1 h, media were again aspirated, and newly synthesized proteins were metabolically labeled by incubating the cells in methionine-free DMEM/F12 containing 5% dialyzed FBS to which 50 μCi/ml [35S]methionine (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) had been added. Human peripheral blood monocytes were labeled 24 h postisolation and plating as for the macrophages above. In all cases, cells were maintained at 37 °C, 5% CO2 for 48 h before radiolabeled media were harvested for immunoprecipitation of radiolabeled proteins. Radiolabeled conditioned media were diluted 1:1 with a buffer containing 50 mm Tris, pH 8, 20 mm EDTA, and 0.8% Triton X-100. Samples were then “precleared” to diminish nonspecifically binding proteins by rotating end-over-end for 1 h at room temperature with 45 μl of a 50% slurry of Protein A-Sepharose (Zymed Laboratories Inc., San Francisco, CA). Although activated macrophages have the capacity to produce several matrix metalloproteinases, unstimulated cells secrete nearly undetectable levels of several MMPs, including collagenase-1 (Ref. 18Welgus H.G. Campbell E.J. Cury J.C. Eisen A.Z. Senior R.M. Wilhelm S.M. Goldberg G.I. J. Clin. Invest. 1990; 86: 1496-1502Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar; Fig.1, lane 1). MMP synthesis by macrophages is induced upon their activation as evidenced by collagenase-1 secretion after treatment with lipopolysaccharide (Fig.1, lane 2). Incubation with purified recombinant SP-D also induces biosynthesis of collagenase-1 by alveolar macrophages in a dose-dependent manner (Fig. 1, lanes 3–5). Maximal stimulation was in the physiologically relevant range of 1–10 μg/ml SP-D (11Tino M.J. Wright J.R. Am. J. Physiol. 1999; 276: L164-L174PubMed Google Scholar). Even 1 μg/ml SP-D resulted in collagenase-1 production roughly equivalent to that seen with maximal LPS stimulation. It should be noted that, based upon electrophoretic mobility, treatment with either reagent yielded the catalytically active form of the metalloproteinase. Fig. 3shows that no collagenase-1 was detected during the first 4 h of treatment. Secretion increased linearly after 24 h post-treatment, yielding a final production that was calculated to be 0.95 μg of collagenase-1/106 cells/24 h. In addition to collagenase-1 secretion, alveolar macrophages can synthesize and secrete several additional metalloproteinases, including gelatinase B (92-kDa gelatinase or MMP-9), stromelysin (MMP-3), and macrophage elastase (MMP-12). Under in vitro culture conditions, MMP-9 is secreted constitutively, while MMP-3 and -12 are synthesized following treatment with an activating agent such as LPS. Immunoprecipitation assays were performed to assess whether the biosynthesis of these proteinases was also modulated in response to SP-D. Fig.4 indicates that production of both MMP-3 and -12 were induced by SP-D treatment (Fig. 4, panels C andB, respectively), while the biosynthesis of MMP-9 was unchanged (Fig. 4, panel A). Macrophage activation, as classically defined by tumoricidal and phagocytic capacity, is fully induced by treatment with both LPS and interferon γ. LPS alone induces macrophage production of reactive oxygen species and nitric oxide (41Salvemini D. Mollace V. Pistelli A. Anggard E. Vane J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 982-986Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar) as well as secretion of various inflammatory mediators including TNFα and IL-1β (42Hempel S.L. Monick M.M. Hunninghake G.W. Am. J. Respir. Cell Mol. Biol. 1996; 14: 170-176Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). J. 1992; 286: 5-8Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar) but does not significantly increase the production of nitric oxide in the absence of contaminating endotoxin (43Wright J.R. Zlogar D.F. Taylor J.C. Zlogar T.M. Restrepo C.I. Am. J. Physiol. 1999; 276: L650-L658Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). To further investigate the ability of SP-D to induce a more generalized cellular activation, secretion of both TNFα and IL-1β were measured using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays following exposure of alveolar macrophages to either recombinant surfactant protein or optimal concentrations of LPS. Results for each of these assays are shown in Fig.5. As expected, LPS induced a significant increase in the production of both TNFα and IL-1β. By contrast, neither cytokine was significantly up-regulated in response to SP-D. While MMPs are secreted by a number of different cell types, the mediators that regulate production are often cell-specific. To investigate the cell type specificity of the SP-D response, interstitial fibroblasts, peripheral blood monocytes and macrophages derived from in vitro differentiation of monocytes were treated with the surfactant protein, and immunoprecipitation assays for MMPs were performed. The results shown in Fig.6 demonstrate that in contrast to both alveolar and in vitro differentiated macrophages of nonsmokers, peripheral blood monocytes do not secrete MMP-1 and minimal amounts of MMP-12 after stimulation with SP-D (but not LPS) (not shown). Fibroblasts do not produce MMP-1 in response to SP-D. Fibroblasts do, however, synthesize this proteinase in response to treatment with PMA (Fig. 6, panel a, lane 2). To further characterize the mechanism of MMP induction, we examined the effects of a known competing ligand, phosphatidylinositol (PI), on macrophage MMP biosynthesis. An immunoprecipitation assay for collagenase-1 following treatment with P

The stereochemistry of the interactions between quinoxaline antagonists and the ligand-binding domain of the glutamate receptor 4 (GluR4) have been investigated by probing their vibrational modes using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. In solution, the electron-withdrawing nitro groups of both compounds establish a resonance equilibrium that appears to stabilize the keto form of one of the cyclic amide carbonyl bonds. Changes in the 6,7-dinitro-2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline vibrational spectra on binding to the glutamate receptor, interpreted within the framework of a published crystal structure, illuminate the stereochemistry of the interaction and suggest that the binding site imposes a more polarized electronic bonding configuration on this antagonist. Similar spectral changes are observed for 6-cyano-7-dinitro-2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline, confirming that its interactions with the binding site are highly similar to those of 6,7-dinitro-2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline and leading to a model of the 6-cyano-7-dinitro-2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline-S1S2 complex, for which no crystal structure is available. Conformational changes within the GluR ligand binding domain were also monitored. Compared with the previously reported spectral changes seen on binding of the agonist glutamate, only a relatively small change is detected on antagonist binding. This correlation between the functional effects of different classes of ligand and the magnitude of the spectroscopic changes they induce suggests that the spectral data reflect physiologically relevant conformational processes. This correlation between the functional effects of different classes of ligand and the magnitude of the spectroscopic changes they induce suggests that the spectral data reflect physiologically relevant conformational processes. glutamate receptor Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy 6-cyano-7-dinitro-2,3- dihydroxyquinoxaline 6,7-dinitro-2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline α-amino-5-methyl-3-hydroxy-4-isoxazole propionate Glutamate receptor (GluR)1 ion channels are the predominant mediators of excitatory synaptic signals in the central nervous system. Glutamate binding triggers the channels to open, permitting cations to flow down their electrochemical gradients, depolarizing the postsynaptic membrane and thereby stimulating the receiving cell. According to agonist affinity profiles, the GluR can be subdivided into three subfamilies: α-amino-5-methyl-3-hydroxy-4-isoxazole propionate (AMPA),N-methyl-d-aspartate, and kainate receptors (1Wisden W. Seeburg P.H. Curr. Opin. Neurobiol. 1993; 3: 291-298Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar,2Hollmann M. Heinemann S. Annu. Rev. Neurosci. 1994; 17: 31-108Crossref PubMed Scopus (3660) Google Scholar). Recent large scale expression of the extracellular ligand binding domains of two AMPA receptor subunits, namely GluR2 and GluR4, has paved the way for a number of structural and spectroscopic investigations. This ligand binding domain, known as S1S2, retains ligand binding parameters quite similar to those of the intact receptor and hence serves as an excellent model to study the ligand-protein interactions of the complete molecule (3Kuusinen A. Arvola M. Keinänen K. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 6327-6332Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar, 4Lampinen M. Pentikainen O. Johnson M.S. Keinänen K. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4704-4711Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar, 5Chen G.-Q. Gouaux E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 13431-13436Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar, 6Abele R. Keinänen K. Madden D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 21355-21363Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Crystal structures have been determined for the GluR2S1S2 protein in the apo form and in complex with kainate, glutamate, 6,7-dinitro-2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline (DNQX), and AMPA (7Armstrong N. Gouaux E. Neuron. 2000; 28: 165-181Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar). These structures indicate that the ligand binding domain is a bilobate structure and that the degree of cleft closure between the two lobes is related to the type of ligand bound to the protein (7Armstrong N. Gouaux E. Neuron. 2000; 28: 165-181Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar). Full agonists such as glutamate and α-amino-5-methyl-3-hydroxy-4-isoxazole propionate induce a 20° closure of the two domains relative to the apo form, whereas the partial agonist kainate induces only a 12° closure of the two domains (7Armstrong N. Gouaux E. Neuron. 2000; 28: 165-181Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar). On the other hand, the antagonist DNQX-bound form does not exhibit any large conformational changes relative to the apo form (7Armstrong N. Gouaux E. Neuron. 2000; 28: 165-181Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar). These results suggest that the degree of domain closure most likely controls the extent of channel activation, thus providing the first structural insight into the activation mechanism of the glutamate receptors. The interactions of the ligands kainate and glutamate with GluR4-S1S2 have also been investigated using vibrational spectroscopy (8Jayaraman V. Keesey R. Madden D.R. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 8693-8697Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). The ability to assign vibrational modes to individual functional groups using site-specific isotopic labeling, coupled with the high inherent sensitivity of these vibrations to the electronic environments of the groups, permitted a detailed investigation of the interactions between each of the carboxylate moieties of the ligands with the protein. Furthermore, the amide I vibrations of the protein backbone, which are sensitive to the secondary structure of the protein, indicated larger and different changes in the protein on binding glutamate relative to kainate, consistent with the crystallographic data (7Armstrong N. Gouaux E. Neuron. 2000; 28: 165-181Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar). The spectroscopic results extended the structural information by providing a more detailed picture of the strength of the important interactions between the ligand and protein and within the protein. In this study, we performed similar investigations of the interactions of the antagonists DNQX and 6-cyano-7-nitro-2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline (CNQX) with GluR4-S1S2 using vibrational spectroscopy. Because of the presence of electron-withdrawing nitro and cyano substituents, the cyclic amide groups of the free quinoxaline GluR antagonists exist in both delocalized (enol) and localized (keto) bonding configurations; interactions with the GluR binding site specifically stabilize one of these configurations. The DNQX vibrational frequency shifts also provide valuable information on the stereochemistry of the binding interactions and can be used to interpret the published crystal structure of the S1S2-DNQX complex (7Armstrong N. Gouaux E. Neuron. 2000; 28: 165-181Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar). This complex in turn serves as a reference for modeling the interactions in the CNQX complex, which has not been structurally characterized but which we have analyzed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy. Fig. 1 shows the structures of DNQX, CNQX, and the isotopomers used in this study. The isotopomers of DNQX were synthesized using the following reaction scheme. Equimolar quantities of o-phenylenediamine and either oxalic acid or 1,2-13C-oxalic acid (Campro Scientific) were condensed in 4 n hydrochloric acid under reflux to 2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline or 2,3-13C2-2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline, respectively. The recrystallized (ethanol) products were nitrated in concentrated H2SO4using KNO3 at temperatures increasing from 0 °C to room temperature. The mononitrated products were isolated and purified and subjected to a second nitration step under identical conditions. 2,3-Dihydroxyquinoxaline was 15N-labeled by two-step nitration with K15NO3. The labeled and unlabeled 6,7-dinitro-2,3-dihydroxyquinoxalines were stirred in ethanol (absolute, twice), filtered, and dried. 7-15NO2-CNQX was prepared by nitration of 6-cyano-2,3-dihydroxyquinoxaline in 98% H2SO4with a large excess of K15NO3 at 0 °C. 1H NMR spectra (500 MHz, dimethylsulfoxide-d6) exhibited the expected resonances for the isotopomers of DNQX (S, 2H, 7.718 ppm; and S, (−OH)2, 12.448 ppm) and CNQX (S, 1H, 7.558 ppm; D, 1H, 8.038–8.043 ppm; S, −OH, 12.432 ppm; and S, −OH, 12.472 ppm). The chemical purity of the isotopomers was >99%. Mass spectra revealed the expected peak at m/z 254 for both 2,3-13C2-DNQX and 6,7-(15NO2)2-DNQX, with 99 and 95% isotopic purity, respectively, and the expected peak at m/z233 for 7-15NO2-CNQX, with 95% isotopic purity. The GluR4-S1S2 protein was expressed, purified, and characterized as described (9Madden D.R. Abele R. Andersson A. Keinänen K. Eur. J. Biochem. 2000; 267: 4281-4289Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). In brief, S1S2 was expressed as a secreted construct in the baculovirus system. After clarification and concentration of the cell-culture supernatant, it was purified to homogeneity by immunoaffinity and ion exchange chromatography. The protein was concentrated and dialyzed to yield a final concentration of 0.25–0.5 mm in 25 mm phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, containing 250 mmNaCl and 0.02% NaN3. Protein-bound spectra were obtained in the presence of saturating concentrations of DNQX and CNQX. Because water has a large infrared absorption band at ∼1600 cm−1, D2O was used as the solvent to obtain spectra in the 1450–1800 cm−1 region. However, for studying the CN stretching vibration that occurs at ∼2200 cm−1, water was used as the solvent. The FTIR spectra were measured on a Nicolet Magna 870 infrared spectrophotometer using an FTIR cell with CaF2 windows and a 50-μm spacer. Spectra were collected at 4 cm−1 spectral resolution. A modified variable-length sample holder (Aldrich), which allowed liquid from a constant temperature bath to be circulated around the holder, ensured that the protein solutions were kept at a constant temperature of 15 °C. All spectra reported are difference spectra, and the subtraction was performed using the band at 2045 cm−1arising from the sodium azide present in the buffer as an internal standard. Furthermore, for generating the difference spectra between the ligand-bound and apo forms of the protein, the peaks that arise from excess unbound ligand (DNQX, CNQX, and isotopomers thereof) were subtracted using the spectrum of free ligand. The FTIR spectrum of DNQX at pH 7.4 is shown in Fig. 1,trace A. Comparison of the spectrum to spectra of DNQX isotopomers labeled at the carbonyl (13CO-DNQX) or nitro (15NO2-DNQX) positions (Fig. 1, traces B and C, respectively) reveals that the amide, nitro, and aromatic ring moieties of DNQX are the main infrared active chromophores in the 1450–1800 cm−1 region. The assignments are described in detail below and are summarized in TableI.Table IVibrational frequency modes of DNQX and CNQX in D2O and in complex with GluR4 S1S2LigandAmide IAromatic ring stretchAmide IIAsym. NO2StretchCN (substituent) StretchD2OS1S2D2OS1S2D2OS1S2D2OS1S2D2OS1S2cm−1DNQX1690, 16621689161416191547154015421545, 1527CNQX1693, 16631693161816231550153615232243, 22292247 Open table in a new tab 13C labeling at the two carbonyl positions of DNQX (13CO-DNQX) downshifts all the bands in the infrared spectra of DNQX in the 1450–1800 cm−1 region (Fig. 1,traces A and B) except for a band at 1542 cm−1, which corresponds to the asymmetric vibration of the nitro groups, as identified by 15N labeling (see below). The DNQX bands at 1690 and 1662 cm−1 (Fig. 1, trace A) are downshifted to 1647 and 1624 cm−1, respectively, in 13CO-DNQX (Fig. 1, trace B), indicating that they arise from amide I-type CO stretching vibrations of the DNQX cyclic amide groups (10Spiro T.G. Biological Applications of Raman Spectroscopy. Wiley, New York1987Google Scholar). The presence of two amide I vibrations suggests that the carbonyl groups in free DNQX at pH 7.4 can adopt multiple bonding configurations, as illustrated in Fig.2. The high and low frequency vibrations would thus correspond, respectively, to strongly (e.g. Fig.2, keto group in Structure I) or weakly (e.g.Fig. 2, partial double bonds in Structures I andII) localized carbonyl double bonds. In the absence of electron-withdrawing substituents, the carbonyl moieties would be expected to be delocalized at neutral pH, but in DNQX the keto form is apparently stabilized by resonance structures (e.g. Fig. 2,Structure I) made possible by the presence of the electron-withdrawing nitro groups. This interpretation is supported by the differential sensitivities of the 1690- and 1662-cm−1 bands to pH (Fig. 2). Increasing the pH from 7.4 to 10 should titrate the amide protons, as illustrated in Fig. 2, Structures III and IV, leaving the carbonyl groups with little or no double bond character. As predicted, at pH 10, no band is observed at 1690 cm−1, whereas a much weaker signal is obtained at 1662 cm−1(Fig. 2, trace B). An accompanying pH-induced shift is observed in the frequency and intensity of the amide II band found at 1547 cm−1 in the pH 7.4 spectrum (Fig. 2, traces A and C), which has been identified on the basis of its frequency and ∼34-cm−1 downshift on 13CO labeling (Fig. 1, trace B). The amide II shifts observed at pH 10 can be attributed to changes in the composition of the band from a hybrid CN stretching and NH bending mode (Fig. 2, Structures I and II), to a predominantly CN stretching vibration (Fig. 2, Structures III and IV, and Ref. 10Spiro T.G. Biological Applications of Raman Spectroscopy. Wiley, New York1987Google Scholar). The band at 1614 cm−1 in the spectrum of DNQX at pH 7.4 (Fig. 1, trace A) can be assigned to an aromatic ring-breathing mode on the basis of its frequency and its relatively small shift on 13CO labeling (Fig. 1, trace B), which presumably reflects coupling of the benzene and adjacent cyclic amide rings. 15N labeling of the DNQX nitro groups at pH 7.4 downshifts a shoulder on the band at ∼1547 cm−1 (Fig. 1,trace A) to 1510 cm−1 (Fig. 1, trace C). The frequency of the shoulder peak in the unlabeled molecule is 1542 cm−1, as revealed by a shift of the overlapping amide II peak from 1547 to 1513 cm−1 on 13CO labeling (Fig. 2, trace B). On the basis of its frequency and ∼30-cm−1 downshift on 15NO2labeling, the 1542-cm−1 band can be assigned to the asymmetric stretching vibrations of the DNQX nitro groups. The resonance structure invoked above to explain the presence of two DNQX amide I vibrational modes (Fig. 2, Structure I) also implies the existence of two distinct bonding configurations of the nitro groups. However, only a single nitro vibrational mode is detected. One explanation is that there is little difference between the asymmetric vibrational frequencies of the two NO2bonding configurations and that the band observed at 1542 cm−1 represents a hybrid of two unresolved component frequencies. Consistent with this interpretation, an increase in pH from 7.4 to 10 causes the band to shift, but only by 5 cm−1 (data not shown), presumably reflecting selective stabilization of the uncharged form of the nitro moiety (Fig. 2,Structures III and IV). The structures of DNQX and CNQX are very similar, except that a single nitro group in DNQX is replaced by a cyano group in CNQX (Fig. 1). As a result, their spectra are also comparable (Fig. 1, traces A andD), and the assignments made by isotopic labeling of DNQX can be transferred to the CNQX spectrum. The small upshifts in the amide I, amide II, and aromatic ring vibrations of CNQX relative to DNQX (Fig. 1 and Table I) can be attributed to the fact that the CNQX cyano group is less electron-withdrawing than the corresponding DNQX nitro moiety. Like DNQX, free CNQX in solution exhibits dual amide I vibrational modes at pH 7.4 (Fig. 1, trace D), presumably also reflecting the existence of alternative bonding configurations (Fig. 2,Structures I and II). In the case of CNQX,Structure I in Fig. 2 is resolved into two distinct structures by the nonequivalence of the 6 and 7 substituents (Fig.3, Structures I andII). The amide I equilibrium should thus be coupled to the stretching vibration of the CNQX cyano group; the FTIR spectrum exhibits the expected two bands in the region of the CN stretching vibration (Fig. 3, trace A). The frequency of the asymmetric stretching vibration(s) of the single NO2 group of CNQX is revealed by the difference spectrum between CNQX and 15NO2-labeled CNQX (Fig. 1,trace E). The positive band at 1536 cm−1reflects asymmetric vibrations of the unlabeled NO2group. As for DNQX, this mode is likely to represent a hybrid of the component frequencies associated with the two different nitro group configurations shown in Figs. 2 and 3. The FTIR difference spectrum between DNQX-bound protein and apo protein (Fig.4, trace A) reflects changes in the vibrational modes of both DNQX and the protein. Difference spectra have also been obtained between complexes of protein with unlabeled DNQX and with DNQX isotopomers (Fig. 4, traces Band C). Isotopic labeling is essential not only to assign bands to specific DNQX functional group vibrations but also to detect bands that are masked in the unlabeled difference spectrum (e.g. Fig. 4, 1500–1550 cm−1) because of overlap between the protein and DNQX difference features. The assignments of the individual bound vibrational modes are described below and summarized in Table I. In the difference spectrum between DNQX bound to protein and13CO-DNQX bound to protein (Fig. 4, trace B), a positive band at 1689 cm−1 is downshifted by13CO labeling to yield a negative band at 1647 cm−1, indicating that it corresponds to an amide I vibration of bound DNQX. A second positive band at 1540 cm−1 is downshifted by isotopic labeling to 1506 cm−1, suggesting that it corresponds to an amide II vibration. Two small difference features are observed in the difference spectrum between DNQX-bound S1S2 and apo-S1S2 at 1619 and 1597 cm−1 (Fig. 4, trace A). On the basis of their frequency, these have been tentatively assigned to benzene ring vibrations of bound DNQX. The difference spectrum between DNQX bound to protein and15NO2-DNQX bound to protein (Fig. 4,trace C) has two positive overlapping bands at 1545 and 1527 cm−1 which are downshifted by15NO2 labeling to 1514 and 1504 cm−1, respectively, suggesting that they can be assigned to the two NO2 groups of the bound DNQX. As shown in Table I, S1S2 binding clearly affects the vibrational spectra of the DNQX nitro and cyclic amide moieties. Although the difference between the two bonding configurations of the DNQX nitro groups is too small to be resolved in solution, their distinct interactions with the S1S2 binding site upshift one asymmetric stretching vibration slightly and downshift the other significantly. At the carbonyl groups, the interaction with S1S2 simultaneously stabilizes the high frequency (keto) bonding configuration and apparently eliminates the low frequency (enol) configuration observed in free DNQX. Interpreted within the framework of crystallographic data on the S1S2-DNQX complex (7Armstrong N. Gouaux E. Neuron. 2000; 28: 165-181Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar), these spectroscopic data establish the electronic bonding configuration of the bound antagonist and provide the basis for a model of the S1S2-CNQX interaction, which has not yet been structurally characterized. Comparing the dual frequencies of the nitro groups of bound DNQX (1545 and 1527 cm−1) with the corresponding single hybrid frequency (1542 cm−1) of the two nitro groups in free DNQX (Table I), it is evident that one of the bands is downshifted by ∼15 cm−1. This indicates that one of the nitro groups has become more electron-withdrawing, has formed a hydrogen-bonding interaction with the protein, or both. The other band is slightly upshifted by ∼3 cm−1 relative to the hybrid frequency, which would be consistent with a more negative electrostatic environment for the other nitro group in the binding pocket. In the crystal structure of the DNQX-bound GluR2 ligand binding domain (7Armstrong N. Gouaux E. Neuron. 2000; 28: 165-181Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar), two different complexes are observed in the asymmetric unit. In one complex, a sulfate ion is located in the binding pocket together with the DNQX molecule, causing small but significant rearrangements of both ligand and protein side-chain moieties relative to the second, sulfate-free complex. In the sulfate-bound complex, each DNQX nitro group makes a single weak hydrogen bond to S1S2 (3.4 Å to Tyr-733 and 3.5 Å to Thr-687, respectively, using GluR4 sequence numbering) and another hydrogen bond to a water molecule (2.7 and 3.2 Å, respectively), and each is 3.4–3.7 Å from the closest protein carboxylate moieties (Glu-403 and Glu-706). Approximately equivalent shifts would therefore be expected for the two groups relative to their (overlapping) frequencies in solution, in contrast to the unequal effects seen in the vibrational spectra (Table I). In the sulfate-free complex (Fig.5), the DNQX nitro group that is distal to the S1S2 hinge makes a single 3.0-Å hydrogen bond to Thr-687 in S1S2 and is distant (≥4.5 Å) from both protein carboxylates, so that a downshift of the observed magnitude would be expected for this group. The hinge-proximal nitro group makes hydrogen bonds to Tyr-733 (2.7 Å) and to a water molecule (2.6 Å) but is located 3.2 Å from the negatively charged carboxylate of Glu-403 and 4.3 Å from the Glu-706 carboxylate. The competing influences of these interactions would be consistent with the small upshift we observe for the other nitro group. Our data therefore suggest that the sulfate-free crystal structure more accurately reflects the DNQX complex formed in solution. Furthermore, the negative electrostatic environment (Glu-403 and Glu-706) of the hinge-proximal nitro group causes the hinge-distal nitro group to be more electron-withdrawing, thus favoring the specific DNQX bonding structure shown in Fig. 5. The negative charge on the hinge-distal nitro group imposes a keto configuration on the opposite, hinge-proximal carbonyl group (Fig. 5), consistent with the high frequency amide I band observed in the bound DNQX and CNQX spectra. The localized double bond at the hinge-proximal carbonyl group is also stabilized by the hydrogen-bonding interaction of Pro-479 with the hinge-proximal amide proton (Fig. 5). In parallel, the absence of an enol vibrational mode suggests that a negatively charged single-bonded configuration is induced at the hinge-distal carbonyl group by electrostatic interactions with the nearby positively charged Arg-486 guanidino moiety (2.8 Å). The structure stabilized by the sum of these interactions would therefore exhibit a single, high frequency amide I vibrational mode, as observed. S1S2 binding has broadly similar effects on the distribution of CNQX vibrational frequencies as it does for DNQX. In the FTIR difference spectrum between CNQX-S1S2 and apo-S1S2 (Fig. 4, trace D), the positive bands at 1693 and 1623 cm−1 can be assigned in analogy to the corresponding bands at 1689 and 1619 cm−1in the bound DNQX spectrum. The four-wave number upshift in these vibrations in bound CNQX versus DNQX (Fig. 4) mirrors the similar upshift in the corresponding frequencies of free CNQXversus DNQX caused by the weaker electron-withdrawing character of the CNQX cyano group (Table I). It thus appears that S1S2 binding stabilizes the same carbonyl bonding configuration in CNQX as it does in DNQX, with one single bond and one strongly localized double bond. In the difference spectrum between CNQX bound to protein and15NO2-CNQX bound to protein (Fig. 4,trace E), there is one positive band at 1523 cm−1, which is downshifted to 1500 cm−1 by isotopic labeling of the NO2 moiety. The band at 1523 cm−1 can therefore be assigned to the asymmetric vibrational frequency of the single NO2 group of bound unlabeled CNQX. The cyano stretching vibrational mode of the bound CNQX (Fig. 3, trace B), on the other hand, exhibits a single peak that is upshifted by 4 cm−1 from the highest frequency band of free CNQX. The similar effects of S1S2 binding on the vibrational frequencies of DNQX and CNQX suggest a highly conserved stereochemical interaction of both antagonists with the binding pocket. Within this framework, the behavior of the vibrational frequencies of the CNQX cyano and nitro moieties permits us to identify their likely positions in the S1S2 ligand binding pocket. The 13-cm−1 downshift in the asymmetric vibration of the single CNQX nitro group is comparable with the 15-cm−1 downshift assigned to the hinge-distal nitro group of DNQX. As a result, the CNQX nitro group would be expected to carry a negative charge and to occupy the hinge-distal nitro binding site (Fig. 5). The resulting bonding configuration of S1S2-bound CNQX is also reflected in the behavior of the cyano stretching vibration, for which only a single peak is found, in contrast to the dual peaks observed in the free form (Fig. 3). The high frequency of this peak corresponds to the less conjugated form of the cyano group (Fig. 3,Structure I), consistent with the negative charge being located on the nitro group in the S1S2-bound state (Fig. 5). Furthermore, assuming that the nitro group occupies the hinge-distal position as postulated, the cyano group would have to be placed in the negative electrostatic environment of the hinge-proximal binding site, which would further localize the electrons and in addition decrease the conjugation between the CN group and the CNQX aromatic ring. Consistent with this prediction, the frequency of the cyano stretching vibration in the difference spectrum of bound CNQX, (2247 cm−1) is four wave numbers higher than the higher of the two frequency bands observed in free CNQX (2243 cm−1). Although most of the bands in the difference spectra of DNQX-S1S2 and CNQX-S1S2versus apo S1S2 (Fig. 4, traces A andD) can thus be assigned to vibrational modes of the bound antagonist, this is not the case for the features at 1645 and 1644 cm−1, respectively. The frequency of these bands appears not to be shifted by isotopic labeling of the antagonists, nor is the CNQX frequency upshifted relative to the DNQX frequency, as seen for most antagonist vibrational frequencies. The frequencies and lack of agonist sensitivity of these bands suggest that they reflect the amide I vibrational mode of α-helices in the protein (10Spiro T.G. Biological Applications of Raman Spectroscopy. Wiley, New York1987Google Scholar, 11Byler D.M. Susi H. Biopolymers. 1986; 25: 469-487Crossref PubMed Scopus (2708) Google Scholar), and positive bands in the difference spectra thus indicate a modest increase in the α-helical content of the S1S2 domain on binding of the quinoxaline antagonists. The increase appears to be similar for DNQX and CNQX, suggesting that both compounds induce similar, small conformational changes in the binding domain. Compared with the modest effect of the antagonists DNQX and CNQX, much more extensive changes in the vibrational spectra of GluR4 S1S2 have been described on binding of full and partial agonists (8Jayaraman V. Keesey R. Madden D.R. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 8693-8697Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). The full agonist glutamate induces a significant increase in β-sheet content and simultaneous moderate increases in both α-helical and turn contents (8Jayaraman V. Keesey R. Madden D.R. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 8693-8697Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). Similar changes in β-sheet and turn contents and a small increase in α-helical content are observed on binding of the partial agonist kainate (8Jayaraman V. Keesey R. Madden D.R. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 8693-8697Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). 2S. Thiran, R. Madden, and V. Jayaraman, unpublished data.Thus, there is a correlation between the magnitude of the infrared spectral changes and the extent of channel activation induced by GluR ligands. Furthermore, as outlined in the Introduction, the extent of spectral changes mirrors the crystallographically observed differences in the extent of domain closure on the binding of antagonists, partial agonists, and full agonists (7Armstrong N. Gouaux E. Neuron. 2000; 28: 165-181Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (792) Google Scholar). It is therefore likely that infrared spectral changes reflect physiologically relevant conformational changes in the binding domain. Infrared spectroscopy can be used to refine and extend the information provided by crystal structures. Here, the availability of isotopically labeled quinoxaline antagonists has revealed their electronic configurations and charge distributions as stabilized either in solution or by their interactions with the glutamate receptor binding site. This information is not directly accessible to crystallographic analysis alone but rather to a combination of structural and spectroscopic techniques. In addition, FTIR difference spectra confirm the similarity of the binding interactions of both CNQX and DNQX with S1S2 and permit us to model the previously uncharacterized CNQX interaction on the basis of the crystal structure of the DNQX-S1S2 complex. Finally, the vibrational spectra detect subtle changes in protein secondary structure content that appear to distinguish clearly the conformational effects of different functional classes of ligands, including antagonists, partial agonists, and full agonists. The ability to monitor such conformational changes spectroscopically may ultimately permit a time-resolved analysis of the conformational changes induced by agonist binding.
